editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

By meanes of that delay ≈øpace was giuen to Vitellius men to flee into the vines, where, by rea≈øon of the branches wrapped and knit one in another, it was trouble≈øome to follow: and a little wood adioyned which couered theÃÑ; out of which they i≈ø≈øued eft≈øones & ≈ølew the formo≈øt of the Praetorian hor≈øemen. thereKing of what countrey? and how came he thither? and what became of him afterward? great per≈øons in a ≈øtory require, in my opinion, a more exact and particulare de≈øcription. king Epiphanes, fighting valiantly on Othoes ≈øide, was wounded. In the campe al≈øo a mutinee aro≈øe, becau≈øe they were fetched ≈øo ≈øcatteringly, and Iulius Gratus the Camp-ma≈øter was put in pri≈øon, as though in fauour of his brother, who ≈øerued vnder Otho, hee intended ≈øome trea≈øon; whereas the Othonians had, on the other ≈øide, committed to ward Iulius Fronto his brother, a Tribune, vpon colour of the ≈øame crime. But in trueth euery where the feare was ≈øo great, in tho≈øe which fled, in tho≈øe which met them, in the field and at the campe, that vnle≈ø≈øe Suetonius Paullinus had ≈øounded the retrayt, not ≈øuffering his men to follow the victory, it was commonly talked on both ≈øides, that Caecina might haue beene de≈øtroied with his whole army. Paullinus pretended that hee was afeard, le≈øt, be≈øide ≈øo much trauaile and ≈øo great a iourney, the Vitellian ≈øouldier ≈øhould haue i≈ø≈øued foorth of their campe fre≈øh again≈øt his men being tired, no ≈øupply remaining behind, if it fortuned

div.head: XII. The de≈øcription of a mutinee which happened in Valens campe. Valens commeth into Jtalie and ioyneth his power with Caecinaes.
div.p:
THIS ouerthrowe did not ≈øo much daunt the Vitelliani≈øts, as it reduced them to a more mode≈øt behauiour, not onely in Caecinaes campe, who ca≈øt the fault on the ≈øouldier more ready to mutin then fight; but the army of Fabius Valens al≈øo (for now he was come to Ticinum) laying a≈øide contempt of the enemy, and de≈øirous to recouer their glory, began to ≈øhew to their Generall a more reuerent and orderly obedience. For before a great and hoate mutinee had happened out, which I will now ≈øet downe from the beginning, albeit not in his proper time, becau≈øe it was not conuenient to interrupt the cour≈øe of Caecinaes actions. The cohortes of Batauians, which in the warre of Nero were departed from the fourteenth Legion, and in their returne towarde Britannie, hearing of Vitellius attempt in the countrey of Lingones, had ioyned them≈øelues,1. Hi≈øt. p. 43. and 45. as before we haue ≈øhewed, to Fabius Valens, began to waxe proud and in≈øolent, vanting and brauing as they came to the tentes of any of the Legions, that they were the men which had ouerruled the fourteenth Legion, bereaued Nero of Italy: that in their handes alone lay all the fortune and whole ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of this warre. That ≈øeemed contumelious to the ≈øouldier, and highly di≈øplea≈øed the Generall, the di≈øcipline being by their wranglings and brawlings corrupted. At the la≈øt Valens, by their in≈øolent behauiour ≈øu≈øpecting perfidiou≈øne≈ø≈øe al≈øo, receiuing adui≈øe, that the wing of the Treueri and Tungrians were beaten by Othoes fleete, and that the prouince of Narbon was in ≈øome danger of inua≈øion, partly vpon a care to defend his friendes and allies, and partly vpon militare pollicy to di≈øper≈øe the≈øe Batauians ≈øo mutinou≈øly affected, and of ≈øo great ≈øtrength if they remained together, commaunded part of the cohorts to goe and relieue them. Which thing when it was heard and noy≈øed abroad, the Auxiliaries mourned, theIt ≈øeemeth ≈øtrange, that the Legions ≈øhould be di≈øplea≈øed with the departure of tho≈øe, who≈øe in≈øolent and contumelious behauiour they could not abide, if Tacitus ≈øay true not pa≈øt ≈øix lines before. Legions ≈øtomacked, lamenting they ≈øhould be depriued in ≈øuch a time of ≈øo maine an a≈øsi≈øtaunce of ≈øuch valiant men: what? ≈øhould tho≈øe ≈øo experienced, and conquerours
in ≈øo many warres, whenas the enemies were within viewe, bee ≈øent away, as it were, out of the field? if the prouince were a matter of more con≈øequence then the citty of Rome and ≈øafety of the ≈øtate, why did they not all followe thither? but if the accompli≈øhment of the victory, the ≈øtrength and ≈øtay of the cau≈øe con≈øi≈øted in Italie, what rea≈øon then to breake off, as it were, the ≈øounde≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt limmes from the bodie? vpon the≈øe and the like pre≈øumpteous ≈øpeeches, whenas Valens by ≈øending his ≈øergeauntes among them, went about to correct their ≈øeditious behauiour, they offred violence to him≈øelfe, threwe ≈øtones, and forcing him to flee, followed after; and crying, that the ≈øpoile of France, the golde of Vienna, and the price of their labours was by him embezeled, and hid, they ≈øpoiled his cariage, they pearced and ≈øearched his pauilions, and the very grounde it ≈øelfe with their lances and dartes: for Valens him≈øelfe in a bondemans apparell lay vnknowen in the tent of an vnder-captaine of hor≈øemen. Then Alphenus Varus the Campe-ma≈øter, perceauing the heate of the mutinee pa≈øt, and the ≈øouldiers by little and little to growe colder, adioyneth a pollicie thereunto: forbidding the Centurions to meddle with ≈øearching and peru≈øing the watch, and omitting to ≈øound the trumpet, by which the ≈øouldier is called to his charge. Whereupon they ≈øtoode all amazed, looking one on another, a≈øtoni≈øhed and di≈ømayed to ≈øee them≈øelues thus without head, or direction: and ≈øo with ≈øilence and patience, and la≈øtly with teares and intreatie be≈øought pardon of their offence. But whenas Valens came foorth aboue all expectation aliue, weeping and badly attired, then was there ioy and compa≈øsion, and a generall fauouring of the man: and chaunging their former affections into gladne≈ø≈øe, as the common ≈øort is in both without mea≈øure, they caried him in the midde≈øt of the Standerds and en≈øeignes, with prai≈øes and gratulations, to the Tribunall. Valens, v≈øing a profitable and di≈øcreete moderation, required not any one to bee executed for this tran≈øgre≈øsion; onely in wordes reproued ≈øome fewe, le≈øt if he di≈ø≈øembled the whole, he ≈øhould be ≈øu≈øpected the more: knowing right well that in ciuill warres the ≈øouldiers haue a vantage ouer the Generall, and are more bolde to commit di≈øorders, then the Generall may be to correct them. As they were entrenching at Ticinum, woorde was
brought of Caecinaes ouerthrowe, and the ≈øedition was almo≈øt renewed againe, as though by fraud and delayes of Valens they had bene kept backe, and come ≈øhort of the battell. Whereupon refu≈øing to re≈øt any longer, without ≈øtaying for their Generall they marche forwarde, running before their en≈øeignes, and ha≈øtening the en≈øeigne-bearers: and ≈øo in all ≈øpeede ioyne with Caecina. Valens was al≈øo di≈øliked and generally blamed in the armie of Caecina: who pretended them≈øelues to bee aggreeued, that they were left, being ≈øo farre inferiour in number, as a pray to the whole power of the enemies; highly extolling withall the ≈øtrength of the other army, partly to excu≈øe them≈øelues, and partly to flatter their fellowes, le≈øt as conquered and cowardly per≈øons they ≈øhoulde bee de≈øpi≈øed of them: and albeit Valens had more forces, almo≈øt double number of Legions and Aides to the other, yet were the goodwilles of the ≈øouldiers more inclining to Caecina, be≈øide curte≈øie, wherein he excelled the other, by rea≈øon al≈øo of his flori≈øhing age, and talne≈ø≈øe of ≈øtature, and vppon a certaine vaine fauour of men. Hereupon there grew emulation betweene the two generalles. Caecina contemned the other, as a lewde per≈øon of life and criminally noted: Valens ≈øcoffed at him as being proude and vaineglorious: but re≈øeruing their hatred in ≈øecrete they ioyned openly both in the common cau≈øe, by many letters, without re≈øpect of pardon, obiecting to Otho his infamous life; whereas the Generalles of Othoes ≈øide, notwith≈øtanding the argument yeelded that way mo≈øt plentifull matter, ab≈øtained from all reuiling ≈øpeeches again≈øt Vitellius: and in trueth before their endes, which on Othoes ≈øide was mo≈øt commendable, of Vitellius mo≈øt ignominious, the drow≈øy plea≈øures of Vitellius were feared le≈ø≈øe, then the hoat burning lu≈øtes of Otho: and be≈øide, the death of Galba had made Otho more terrible, and more odious: contrarily no man charged Vitellius with beginning the warre. Vitellius in exce≈ø≈øe & bellicheere was an enemy to him≈øelfe: Otho in riot, cruelty, audaciou≈øne≈ø≈øe, reputed more dangerous to the ≈øtate.

div.head: XIII. Otho determineth to commit the matter to the hazarde of a battel, and retireth him≈øelfe to Brixellum.
div.p:
THE forces of Caecina and Valens being ioyned together, the Vitelliani≈øts refu≈øed not any longer to end the cau≈øe in a maine
battell. Otho propo≈øed the matter in councell, whether way were more expedient, to prolong the warre, or els to put it by and by to the fortune of a fielde. Then Suetonius Paullinus, e≈øteemed the mo≈øt experte man of that age in militare affayres, ≈øuppo≈øing it agreeable to his fame & renowne, to di≈øcour≈øe of the whole maner of proceeding in this warre, ≈øtoode vp, & declared his opinion to bee; that making of ha≈øte was profitable for the enemy, and delaying for them. that al the ho≈øt of Vitellius was come, certaine ≈ømall forces remaining behinde, which could not conueniently be remoued from the banke of the Rhene, for feare of inua≈øion of tho≈øe fierce nations: e≈øpecially Fraunce ≈øtanding al≈øo in ≈øome tearmes of rebellion: the ≈øouldier in Britannie had his hands full of the enemy there, and was al≈øo ≈øtopped by the ≈øea: that Spaine had no great ≈øtore of ≈øouldiers: the prouince of Narbon was frighted, by rea≈øon of the late inua≈øion by ≈øea, and the ouerthrow which they receiued; and that portion of Italie beyonde the Po, now in the po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of the enemy, was wa≈øted with the pa≈ø≈øage of their army, and hauing no helpe by ≈øea, and by lande ≈øhut in with the Alpes, could not be relieued from abroad: ≈øo that they could no-where haue corne for their men, and an ho≈øt without proui≈øion could not bee entertained. Nowe the Germans, which of all the enemies were mo≈øt terrible, hauing foggy and wateri≈øh bodies, would not, if the warre were prolonged to the ≈øommer, be able to endure the change of the ≈øoile, and the avre. that many armies who≈øe fury at the fir≈øt ru≈øh could not be re≈øi≈øted, by delayes & wearying out were brought vnto nothing. Contrariwi≈øe they had all thinges them≈øelues, well ≈øtoared and well a≈ø≈øured vnto them: Pannonia, Moe≈øia, Dalmatia, the Ea≈øte, with their armies, whole and vntouched; Italie, and Rome the queene of the world, the Senate and people, titles neuer darkened, though ≈øometimes ouer≈øhadowed: wealth priuate and publicke, and infinite ma≈ø≈øes of money, which in ciuill di≈ø≈øen≈øions is of greater force then the ≈øworde: the bodies of their ≈øouldiers were accu≈øtomed to Italie, or to other hoat countreys: the riuer of Po layNot at Bebriacum, where the con≈øultation was holden, but he meaneth if they ≈øhould, as he wi≈øhed, retire with their power in Ci≈øpadanam, and there ≈øtand vpon their defence. before them as a defence: their cities were ≈øafely manned & walled: & by the holding out of Placentia it was cleere to be ≈øeene, that none through di≈øtre≈ø≈øe or de≈øpaire woulde yeelde to the enemy: and therefore in his opinion he was to protract the warre. That within fewe daies the fourteenth Legion would bee come, a Legion of
great reputation, with the forces of Moe≈øia: then might he deliberate againe, and, if it were liked to hazarde the battell, fight with more power and greater aduantage. Marius Cel≈øus approued the opinion of Paullinus, and certaine which were ≈øent to Annius Gallus (who was hurte with a fall of his hor≈øe a few daies before) to demaunde his adui≈øe, brought woorde that hee al≈øo was of the ≈øame iudgement. But Otho was willing to bring it to a battell: his brother Titianus and Proculus captaine of the Gard, ha≈øtening vpon ignoraunce and lacke of ≈økill, prote≈øted, that fortune and all the gods, with the godhead of Otho, fauoured the coun≈øailes, and woulde without que≈øtion pro≈øper the enterpri≈øe: de≈øcending to this gro≈ø≈øe kinde of flattery, le≈øt any ≈øhoulde dare to cro≈ø≈øe their opinion. After they had concluded to fight, a new doubt aro≈øe, whether it were better, that the Emperour ≈øhoulde withdrawe him≈øelfe, or el≈øe be pre≈øent in the fielde in per≈øon: the ≈øelfe≈øame men taking al≈øo herein a wrong cour≈øe, without any more oppo≈øition of Paullinus and Cel≈øus, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øeeme to hazard their Prince too venturou≈øly, per≈øuaded him to retire to Brixellum; and ≈øo being exempt from the doubtful euentes of the field, to re≈øerue him≈øelfe for the maine chance of the ≈øtate. That day was the beginning of ruine to Othoes ≈øide. For with him a valiant companie of Praetorian cohorts, ofSpiculatores ≈øpearemen and hor≈øe departed away: and the re≈øt which remained behinde were quite out of harte, as hauing no confidence in their Generals: and Otho, whom only the ≈øouldiers tru≈øted, becau≈øe he tru≈øted none els but the ≈øouldiers, had not perfitely ≈øetled the Generals in their charges, but left their autorities at large and vncertaine.

div.head: XIIII. A skirmi≈øh betweene the Vitelliani≈øts and Macer with his fencers vpon the Po.
div.p:
ALL that was ≈øaide or done was caried by & by to the Vitellian ≈øide, fugitiues ≈øwarming as in ciuill warres, and the ≈øpyes, vpon de≈øire to ≈øearch out & di≈øcouer other mens coun≈øailes, di≈øclo≈øing their own. Caecina and Valens lay ≈øtill, quietly attending while the enemy ≈øhould by his own ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe mi≈øcary, meaning in liew of wi≈øedome to v≈øe the vaÃÑtage of other mens folly. And ≈øo beginning a bridge, le≈øt their ≈øoldiers ≈øhould be made wor≈øe with too much idlene≈ø≈øe and ea≈øe, as if they had ment to haue pa≈ø≈øed the Po, and
forced a bande ofGladiatores. fencers encaÃÑped on the other ≈øide, they commanded boats to be placed cro≈ø≈øe the riuer, with their heads vp the ≈øtreame, in equall and conuenient di≈øtances, and ioined them ≈øtrongly together with plancks, ca≈øting anckers al≈øo to make the bridge ≈øteady & firme: but the cable ropes were not tied ≈øhort, but plaied at length, that when the riuer ≈øhould ri≈øe, the whole frame likewi≈øe might ri≈øe without hurting. Vpon the end of the bridge a tower was planted, reaching to the vttermo≈øt boate, that out of it they might with their engines and ≈øhot di≈øplace, and driue away the enemies: the Othonians al≈øo vpon the bancke had builded a tower, and did hurle ≈øtones and fire. In the middle of the riuer there was an iland, into po≈ø≈øes≈øion whereof the fencers ≈øought to put them≈øelues by boate, but the Germans by ≈øwimming preuented them; and when Macer ≈øaw a competent number of them arriued there, embarking of his be≈øt fencers, he putteth ouer to a≈ø≈øaile them: but neither were the fencers of the like courage in fight to the ≈øouldiers, neither could they, tottering out of their boats, ayme ≈øo certaine a blow, as the other ≈øteadily ≈øtanding did from the lande: and whenas through ≈øundry ≈øteppings a≈øide vpon feare the rowers and ≈øouldiers, which ≈øtoode at defence, were confu≈øedly mingled together and put in di≈øorder, the German ≈øouldiers leaping couragiou≈øly into the ≈øhallow, and hanging at the tailes of the boats, either clambered vp to the hatches, or by maine ≈øtreÃÑgth ouerturned the boats into the water. All which things pa≈ø≈øing after this ≈øort in the viewThe one lay at Bebriacum, and the other by all coniecture at Cremona, twenty miles a≈øuÃÑder. of both the armies, as they were matter of great ioy to the Vitelliani≈øts, ≈øo to the contrary ≈øide they gaue occa≈øion to hate & dete≈øt him, who was author and cau≈øe of the lo≈ø≈øe. And the skirmi≈øh was ended indeede by flight and the breaking away of the boats which remained; but Macer was required to the ≈ølaughter: & when they had wounded him with a darte a farre of, they ranne in with their ≈øwords drawn to di≈øpatch him, had not the Tribunes and Centurions come in to protect him. A little afterwarde Ve≈øtricius Spurinna by Othoes commaundement, leauing a ≈ømall garri≈øon at Placentia, with his cohortes came to ≈øuccour them: and anone Otho ≈øent Flauius Sabinus Con≈øull elect to commaunde Macers companies, the ≈øouldiers being glad at the change of captaines, and the captaines, by rea≈øon of ≈øo many mutinees, vnwilling to enter into ≈øo dangerous a ≈øeruice.

div.head: XV. That it is nothing probable, that in ≈øo corrupt an age, the ≈øoldier. would of their own accord haue ≈øurcea≈øed from ciuill warre, and by common con≈øent, and adui≈øe of the Senat, depo≈øing the≈øe two bad, haue cho≈øen a third good Prince.
div.p:
IN ≈øome writers I finde it recorded, that the armies, either hauing in horrour the warre, or loathing both Princes, who≈øe ≈øhames and di≈øhonours were daily divulged more notoriou≈øly abroade, con≈øulted among them≈øelues to ≈øurcea≈øe the contention, and that either they by common con≈øent ≈øhould chu≈øe a newe Prince, or referre it ouer to the Senats appointment: and that therefore the Generals of Othoes ≈øide, Plutarch p. 1523. attributeth it to Cel≈øus not ≈øo probably. namely Paullinus, had coun≈øailed to delay and protract, hoping it would fall vpon him, as beeing the mo≈øt auncient Con≈øulare, a famous Commander, and one that in the warres of Britanny had wonne great glory and name. For my part, although I could bee induced to grant that ≈øome fewe peraduenture ≈øecretely wi≈øhed quietne≈ø≈øe in ≈øteede of di≈øcorde, and for two mo≈øt lewde and wicked, one good and innocent Prince; ≈øo I cannot be brought to beleeue, that Paullinus beeing ≈øo wi≈øe a man woulde euer hope in a mo≈øt corrupt age for ≈øuch moderation in the common ≈øorte, that whenas for de≈øire of warre they had troubled the peace of the ≈øtate, nowe for loue of peace they woulde abandon the warre: or that armies in tongue and conditions ≈øo different, coulde conde≈øcende to ≈øo great an agreement: or that the Lieutenantes and Generals, which for the mo≈øt part were per≈øons drowned in riot, beggerly and guilty of mo≈øt hainous crimes, would euer haue ≈øuffered any Prince but one polluted with the like vices, and of their owne creation, and therefore wholly obnoxious to them. That ancient de≈øire of dominion and rule engraffed now long agoe in mens hartes, grewe vp and ≈øhotte out with the greatne≈ø≈øe of the Empire. For while≈øt our dominions were ≈øtrayt, an equality was ea≈øily maintained: but after wee had ≈øubdued the world, de≈øtroied all cities, or kings which ≈øtoode in our light, or might worke our annoiance; whenas we had lei≈øure to ≈øeeke after wealth voide of perill, there aro≈øe fir≈øt hoat contentions betweene the nobility and commons: ≈øometimes factious Tribunes caried it away: ≈øometimes the Con≈øuls held a hard hand & preuailed:
and in the city and Place of a≈ø≈øembly, ≈øome litle skirmi≈øhes, & commencements as it were of ciuill warres, were attempted. Anone after Caius Marius one of the meane≈øt of the comminalty, and Lucius Sulla the cruelle≈øt of all the nobility, by force of armes ouerthrowing the free e≈øtate, induced an ab≈øolute gouernement. After whom Cneius Pompeius ≈øucceeded, ≈øomewhatSalu≈øtius apud Suetonium lib. de claris Grammaticis. Pompeius oris probi, animi
que inuerecundi. ≈øecreter, but nothing better: and after that time neuer was other que≈øtion debated by armes, but who ≈øhould bee ≈øoueraigne Prince of the ≈øtate. The Legions in Phar≈øalia and Philippi, con≈øi≈øting of citizens, were not ≈øo moderately minded: much le≈ø≈øe may wee thinke the armies of Otho and Vitellius would, of their owne accorde, haue layed downe their weapons. The gods were no le≈ø≈øe incen≈øed again≈øt vs: men were no le≈ø≈øe mad and furiou≈øly minded: the ≈øame vices raigning amon≈øt vs haue induced the like di≈ø≈øen≈øions & di≈øcords. That the warres were decided, and ended as it were ech at one ≈øtroke, we are to attribute it to the cowardline≈ø≈øe and faint-hartedne≈ø≈øe of the Princes, and not to the peaceablene≈ø≈øe of the armies. But the recounting of the di≈øpo≈øitions and manners, of pre≈øent & auncient times, hath caried me out of the way. Now I returne to the order of the ≈øtory.

div.head: XVI. The great battell at Bebriacum: wherein Othoes ≈øide was overthrowen.
div.p:
WHen Otho was gone to Brixellum, Titianus his brother caried the countenance and title of General; Proculus captaine of the Garde the power and authority: Paullinus and Cel≈øus, whenas no man employed their wi≈øedome & skill, were captaines only for name≈øake and to be entitled to other mens faults: the Tribunes and Centurions, ≈øeeing the better contemned, & the wor≈øt ≈øort in credit, were doubtfull of the euent: the ≈øouldier notwithding was full of courage and heart, yet ≈øuch as had rather con≈øtrue then execute his Generals commaundementes. It was re≈øolued, that the campe ≈øhould remoue forward, and ≈øit downe in a place fower miles of from Bebriacum, ≈øo without rea≈øon and skill, that although it was ≈øpring time of the yeare, and ≈øo many riuers about them, yet were they di≈øtre≈ø≈øed for water. div.p:

For when word was brought thither of the ouerthrow, the ≈øouldiers reiected the newes as fal≈øe: and ≈øuppo≈øing the Senate to be enemy to Otho, they ob≈øerued their ≈øpeeches, interpreting their countenaunces, and externall behauiour to the wor≈øt; not ab≈øtaining at the la≈øt from reuiling, and contumelious termes, and apparently ≈øeeking an occa≈øion to begin a ma≈ø≈øacre: whereas the Senatours had be≈øide to ≈øtande in feare another way, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øeeme not forward enough to like of Vitellius victory, with whome now all the world was gone. With his owne pur≈øe al≈øo Mutianus furthered the warre, conferring priuately that, which he would in more ample mea≈øure repay him≈øelfe out of the common. The re≈øt following his example in contributing of money, fewe or none had the grace to receiue it againe with the like vantage.

div.head: XXV. The armies in Moe≈øia, Pannonia and Dalmatia adhere to Ve≈øpa≈øian.
div.p:
THE affayres of Ve≈øpa≈øian were in the meane ≈øea≈øon ha≈øtened forward by the Illyrian armies affection towarde the ≈øide. The third Legion gaue example to the other two Legions of Moe≈øia: the ≈øeuenth ≈øurnamed Claudiana, and the eighth, being welwillers of Otho, albeit they were not pre≈øent at the battell, but only come forward Suet. Ve≈øp. c. 6 writeth that not the 3. LegioÃÑs, but 2000 out of the 3. Legions caÃÑe forward to Aquileiat no doubt erroniou≈øly. to Aquileia; at which place mi≈øu≈øing the me≈ø≈øengers that brought worde of Othoes ouerthrowe, and tearing the banners wherein Vitellius name was in≈øcribed, and la≈øtly taking a ≈øumme of money by violence and parting it among≈øt them, they ≈øhewed them≈øelues open enemies to
the cau≈øe. Whereupon they feared di≈øplea≈øure, and vpon feare deui≈øed, that this kinde of dealing, which to Vitellius mu≈øt haue needed a long and ≈øolemne excu≈øe, might to Ve≈øpa≈øian be ≈øet vp and reckened as a fauour and benefit. So the three Moe≈øian Legions, thus concurring in one, by letters inuited the Pannonian armie to the cau≈øe, or if they refu≈øed, prepared to force them. In that tumult Aponius Saturninus Lieutenant general of Moe≈øia endeuoured to commit a mo≈øt wicked act, ≈øending a Centurion to murder Tertius Iulianus Lieutenant of the ≈øeuenth Legion, vpon priuate grudges, pretending the publicke cau≈øe of the ≈øides. Iulianus vnder≈øtanding of the danger, & taking guides skilful in the countrey, fled by the de≈øerts of Moe≈øia, beyonde the mount Hemus, and afterward was not pre≈øent in the ciuill warre of the one ≈øide or other: protracting the iourney he tooke to Ve≈øpa≈øian by diuer≈øe delaies, and as the occurrences were, making le≈ø≈øe ≈øpeede or more. But in Pannonia the thirteenth Legion, and ≈øeuenth ≈øurnamed Galbiana, retaining the anger and griefe of the lo≈øte at Bebriacum, without any ≈øtay ioined them≈øelues to Ve≈øpa≈øian, at the incitement principally of Antonius Primus, a man attainted in law, & in Neroes timeTacitus 14. Ann. p. 497. conuicted of forgery, but among other mi≈øeries of warre and a troubled ≈øtate he recouered his place in the Senate, and by Galba was made Lieutenant of the ≈øeuenth Legion. He was ≈øuppo≈øed to haue written diuer≈øe letters to Otho, offering his ≈øeruice for a captaine to the ≈øide; of whom being not regarded, he was not that warre in any employment: but when as Vitellius ≈øtate beganne to decay, following Ve≈øpa≈øian he added great waight to the cau≈øe, being a man valiant of his hands, of a ready vtterance, a cunning crafte≈øma≈øter to make others odious, in di≈ø≈øen≈øions & mutinees powerable, a violent ≈øpoyler, a wa≈øtful ≈øpender, in time of peace & quiet gouernement in≈øupportable, in warre not to be contemned. The Moe≈øian and Pannonian armies, being thus ioyned together, drew anone the Dalmatian ≈øoldier, albeit the Lieutenaunts generall ≈øturred nothing at al. Titus Flauianus was general of Pannonia, and Pompeius Sullanus of Dalmatia, two wealthy old men: but there was in the countrey Cornelius Fu≈øcus the Procurator, a man in the principal ≈øtrength of his age, and of noble birth; who in his fir≈øt yeares vpon de≈øire of ea≈øe, had renounced his place in Senate, and afterwarde being captaine of his colony in fauour of Galba, by that meanes attained a Procurator≈øhip. This man, entring into the
cau≈øe for Ve≈øpa≈øian, became a principall firebrande of the warre, ≈øeeming to delite not ≈øo much in the rewards of perils, as in the perils them≈øelues, and in ≈øteede of certainties, wherewith he was anciently indued, chu≈øing new and doubtfull vncertainties. So he a≈ø≈øaieth to ≈øhake and ≈øturre vp what≈øoeuer there was any where di≈øcontented, writing into Britanny to the fourteenth Legion, into Spaine to the fir≈øt, becau≈øe they both had ≈øtoode again≈øt Vitellius for Otho: letters al≈øo were ≈øent abroad into France: and ≈øo in one moment there brake a great and mighty warre out, the Illyrian armies thus plainely reuolting, and the re≈øt inclining to followe, where fortune ≈øhould fauour.

div.head: XXVI. Vitellius maketh his entry into Rome.
div.p:
WHILEST the≈øe things were a working in the prouinces, by Ve≈øpa≈øian and his adherents, Vitellius growing euery day more contemptible and ≈ølothfull, ≈øtaying vpon euery place of plea≈øure in towne and country, with his trouble≈øome traine marched toward the citty. Three≈øcore thou≈øand armed men were in the company licentiou≈øly giuen, of lackeyes and hor≈øekeepers a greater number; with infinite vittailers and followers of the campe, the mo≈øt di≈ø≈øolute of all others: be≈øide the traines of ≈øo many Lieutenants and ≈øo many friendes, out of all compa≈ø≈øe of obedience, yea although the gouernours had beene men of great au≈øterity and ≈øtrictne≈ø≈øe. Moreouer the Senatours and gentlemen charged the traine, who came out of the citty to meete him, ≈øome for feare, ≈øome for flattery, the re≈øt and ≈øo all one after another for company, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øeeme to ≈øtay behinde when others did goe. Thither re≈øorted al≈øo of the ba≈øer ≈øort certaine well knowen to Vitellius by meanes of vnhone≈øt ≈øeruices, which in time pa≈øt they had done him, as buffons, ≈øtage players and charet driuers; with which kinde of reprochfull acquaintance he was delited wonderfully. Neither were the colonies onely or free townes impoueri≈øhed by purueying of vittailes for ≈øo huge a company; but the husbandmen them≈øelues, & fieldes, the corne being now ripe, were ≈øpoiled and wa≈øted as an enemie countrey. Many and cruell murders were committed by the ≈øouldiers among them≈øelues, by rea≈øon of the iarring which continued betweene the Legions and Aydes, euer ≈øince the ≈øturre at Ticinum: again≈øt the pezantes, or any third party they agreed but too well:
but the greate≈øt ≈ølaughter was ≈øeuen miles from the citty. At that place Vitellius di≈øtributed to his ≈øouldiers, according to the fa≈øhion of fencers diet, to euery of them meate already dre≈ø≈øed: and the common people, that came out of the citty to ≈øee it, had di≈øper≈øed them≈øelues throughout the whole campe. As the ≈øoldiers gaue no heede to ≈øuch matters, certaine plea≈øants, after a kind of homely ie≈øting, cut away ≈øecretly their belts, and ≈øpoiled them thereof; asking in jybing maner, whether they were girded or no. The ≈øoldiers ≈øtomacke, not v≈øed to beare words of di≈øgrace, could not di≈øge≈øt that ≈øcorne: but with their ≈øwordes reuenged them≈øelues vpon the people which was without weapon: among others the father of one of the ≈øouldiers was ≈ølaine as hee accompanied his ≈øonne: vpon which accident perceiued and noi≈øed abroad they refrained from ≈øhedding of innocent bloud. Notwith≈øtanding in Rome the terrour was great, by rea≈øon of the ≈øouldiers running and gadding thither before. The Place of common a≈ø≈øembly they repaired ≈øpecially to, coueting to behold the place where Galba was ≈ølaine: whenas they them≈øelues were a ≈øpectacle no le≈ø≈øe horrible, with hides of wilde bea≈øts about their backes, & huge ma≈ø≈øy iauelins in their handes, falling to quarrelling, and from quarrelling to blowes and their weapon, whenas thorough their owne lacke of skill they did not auoide the pre≈ø≈øe of the people, or chanced to fall by meanes of the ≈ølippery ≈øtones, or iu≈øtling of others. The Tribunes al≈øo and other captaines in terrible ≈øort, with multitudes of armed men, went ≈øquaring and ietting the ≈øtreetes. Vitellius him≈øelfe riding from the Miluian bridge vpon a goodly cour≈øer with his coate armour on backe, and girded ≈øouldier like, putting the Senate and people before him, had welny made his entry Suetonius c. 11 ≈øaieth plainely he did ≈øo: vrbem ad cla≈ø≈øicum introiit, paludatus ferro
que ≈øuccinctus inter ≈øigna at
que vexilla, ≈øagulatis comitibus, ac detectis commilitonum armis. for this ≈øeemeth to haue bene the maner of entring a towne taken by force. Jo≈øephus. 4. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . c. 35 de≈øcribeth al≈øo this entry. as into a towne taken by foce; but beeing adui≈øed otherwi≈øe by his frendes he laied a≈øide his militare attire, and taking his robes marched with his men in peaceable maner. The Standerds of fower Legions were mar≈øhalled in front, and ≈øo many banners about them out of other Legions: then the en≈øeignes of twelue wings: next to whom were the ranckes of footemen, and behinde them the hor≈øe, and la≈øtly fower and thirty cohorts di≈øtingui≈øhed according to the names of the nations they were of, or kindes of weapons they v≈øed. Before the Standerde marched the Campe-ma≈øters & Tribunes and principal Centurions in white garments, the other Centurions ech with his own bande gli≈øtering all in armour,

Moreouer the citty-≈øouldiery was through vndi≈øcreetne≈ø≈øe or ambition corrupted. Sixteene Praetorian cohorts and foure vrban were enrolled, containing a thou≈øand men a piece. In preferring to tho≈øe roomes Valens pre≈øumed to beare greater ≈øtroake, as being the worthier man, and hauing redeemed Caecina him≈øelfe out of perill: and in trueth by his comming the ≈øide was reuiued, and with ≈øo happy a battell he cancelled the hard opinion of his ≈ølow comming forward: and all the ≈øouldiers of lowe Germanie followed Valens and depended wholly vpon him: vpon which cau≈øes it is ≈øuppo≈øed that Caecinaes faith beganne fir≈øt to be fleeting. Notwith≈øtanding Vitellius yeelded not ≈øo much to the captaines, but that he yeelded much more to the ≈øouldiers plea≈øures: euery one cho≈øe his owne place of ≈øeruice: were he neuer ≈øo vnworthy, if he liked it better hee was deputed to the citty ≈øeruice: againe tho≈øe which were fit were ≈øuffered, if they li≈øted to remaine in their former e≈øtate among the Legionary or Auxiliary ≈øoldiers: which diuer≈øe were willing to doe being mole≈øted with ≈øickne≈ø≈øes, and not able to endure the heat of the countrey. Notwith≈øtanding the Legions and Aydes were drawen of their principall ≈øtrength, and the beauty of the Praetorian campe blemi≈øhed, by this confu≈øion rather then choi≈øe of twenty thou≈øand out of the whole army. As Vitellius was making a ≈øolemne ≈øpeech, the ≈øouldiers required A≈øiaticus, and Flauius, and Rufinus, captaines of France to be executed, becau≈øe they had taken armes in Vindex behalfe: neither did Vitellius re≈øtraine ≈øuch ≈øpeeches, be≈øides that he was a man of weake re≈øi≈øtance by nature, knowing al≈øo that the day of his donatiue was at hand, and the money wanting. Wherefore he granted liberally all other reque≈øts to the ≈øouldier: and to ≈øupply that defect the freedmen of the former Princes were commanded to contribute, according to the number of their bondmen: whereas Vitellius without other care, ≈øaue onely to wa≈øt and con≈øume, builded vp ≈øtables for charet driuers, filled the Race with ≈øpectacles of fencers and wilde bea≈øtes, and as in greate≈øt abundaunce
ca≈øt money mo≈øt idlely away. Furthermore Caecina and Valens with great preparation, and ≈øuch as before that time was neuer ≈øeene, celebrated the birth day of Vitellius, with ≈øhewesGladiatores of fencers in euery ≈øtreete throughout the whole citty. One thing much greeued the good, as it cheered the bad, that Vitellius erected altars in Campus Martius, & there celebrated ≈øolemnely theSuet. c. 11 & ne cui dubium foret quod exemplar regendae reip. elige ‚Ä¢ et, me dio campo Martio, adhibita publicorum ≈øacerdorum f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
quentia, inferias Neronidedit. exequies of Nero. the bea≈øts for the ≈øacrifice were publickly ≈ølaine and burnt: the Augu≈øtales put to the fire: which order of prie≈øts Tiberius Cae≈øar con≈øecrated to the Iulian family, as Romulus did another the like to king Tatius. It was not yet fully foure moneths ≈øince the victory, and Read Suet. Vitellio. c. 12. A≈øiaticus Vitellius freedeman had fully done as much harme, as euer had any Polycletus, or Patrobius, or what≈øoeuer mo≈øt odious name in former courts. No man in that court ≈øought to ri≈øe by vertue or ablene≈ø≈øe: the onely way to credit was with prodigall banquets, and ≈øumptuous cheere to ≈øatiate the vn≈øatiable appetites of Vitellius; who contenting him≈øelfe to enioy the pre≈øent, and caring not any further, is thought in ≈øo fewe moneths to haue wa≈øtedThat is, according to our po≈øitions, ≈øeuen millions thirty one thou≈øand two hundreth and fifty pound ≈øterling. nine hundreth millions of ≈øe≈øterces: a greate and a mi≈øerable citty, which in the ≈øame yeare ≈øupported an Otho and a Vitellius; and that which is more in≈øupportable, a Vinius, a Fabius, an Icelus, and an A≈øiaticus, in great variety of mo≈øt ignominious ≈øortes, vntil ≈øuch time as Mutianus and Eprlut Marcellus, a great oratour, an in≈øtrument of Nero again≈øt Thra≈øea and others, and generally in fauour with all the Princes, vnder whom he liued, as a ≈ømoother of their actions. read Tac. 16. Ann. 2. & 4. Hi≈øt. &c. Marcellus, and rather other men then other manners ≈øucceeded in place.

div.head: XXVIII. The preparation of Vitellius again≈øt Ve≈øpa≈øian.
div.p:
THE reuolt of the third Legion was fir≈øt of all other certefied to Vitellius by letters, written by Aponius Saturninus, before that he al≈øo a≈ø≈øociated him≈øelfe to Ve≈øpa≈øians ≈øide. But neither did Aponius write all, as a man afrighted with the ≈øodainne≈ø≈øe thereof, and be≈øide the frendes of Vitellius flatteringly ≈øought to extenuate and le≈ø≈øen the matter: that it was but a mutince of one Legion alone; a matter of noe moment, ≈øeeing all other armies remained in obedience. After the ≈øame ≈øtile Vitellius al≈øo ≈øpake to the ≈øoldiers, inueying again≈øt the lately ca≈ø≈øed Praetorians, by whome hee affirmed fal≈øe rumours were ≈øpred, and that there was no danger of ciuill warre, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing the name of Ve≈øpa≈øian, and ≈øetting vnderhand ≈øouldiers abroad
in the towne to re≈øtraine the ≈øpeeches of the common people: which thing was a principall meanes to nouri≈øh the fame. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe he ≈øent for Aydes out of Germanie and Britannie, and the Spaines, coldly and di≈ø≈øembling the neces≈øity: the Lieutenants and prouinces on their partes v≈øed the like coldne≈ø≈øe againe. Hordeonius Flaccus Lieutenant of Germanie ≈øu≈øpecting already the reuolt of Batauia, had a warre of his own to care and prouide for. Vectius Bolanus gouerned in Britannie, a cuntrey neuer ≈øo in quiet, that hee could conueniently ≈øpare any number of ≈øouldiers: and be≈øide neither of them were greatly fa≈øt to the ≈øide. Out of the Spaines al≈øo ≈ømall ha≈øt was made: at that time there was no Lieutenant generall there, but onely the Lieutenants of three Legions, of equall autoritie; who as in Vitellius pro≈øperity they would haue contended who ≈øhould haue bene formo≈øt, ≈øo now in his declining e≈øtate they equally drew backe. In Africke the Legion and cohorts leuyed by Clodius Macer, and ≈øtraightwaies di≈ømi≈ø≈øed by Galba, beganne by Vitellius commaundement to re≈øume their ≈øeruice againe: and withall the whole youth of the prouince voluntarily gaue in their names to be ≈øouldiers: for Vitellius had gouerned as Procon≈øull there with good integrity and liking, Ve≈øpa≈øian with as much infamie and hatred of the cuntrey; and accordingly our allies pre≈øumed, they would cary them≈øelues in the Empire: but the triall was otherwi≈øe. And at the beginning Valerius Fe≈øtus the Lieutenant furthered faithfully the endeuours of tho≈øe of the prouince: but anone he faultred, in letters and edicts openly pretending Vitellius, and with ≈øecrete me≈ø≈øages intertayning Ve≈øpa≈øian; meaning to defende the one ≈øide, or the other, according as they ≈øhould happen to pro≈øper. Some Centurions and ≈øouldiers were taken in Rhoetia and France with letters and edicts of Ve≈øpa≈øian about them, and being ≈øent to Vitellius were ≈ølaine: but more e≈øcaped pas≈øing vndi≈øcouered by the ≈øecretne≈ø≈øe of frendes, or by their owne ≈øhifting. So the preparations of Vitellius were knowen abroade: Ve≈øpa≈øians purpo≈øes were for the mo≈øt part vnknowen, partly through the negligence of Vitellius, and partly becau≈øe the Pannonian Alpes were kept with garri≈øon, which ≈øtayed all me≈ø≈øengers: and at ≈øea the Ete≈øians blew, a good wind to ≈øaile ea≈øtward, and contrary from thence.

div.head: XXIX. The ≈øetting forth of Caecina again≈øt the Jllyrian armies, and the beginnings of his trea≈øon.
div.p:
AT length Vitellius terrified with the breaking in of the enemies vpon the frontiers of Italie, and feareful me≈ø≈øages from euery quarter, commandeth Caecina and Valens to make ready for the warre. Caecina was ≈øent before, but Valens ≈øtayed behinde by rea≈øon of his weakne≈ø≈øe in body, being lately recouered of a dangerous ≈øickne≈ø≈øe. Nowe the German army going out of the citty made a farre other ≈øhew then it did at the entry. No quickne≈ø≈øe appeared in their bodies, no courage in their mindes; marching ≈ølowly and thinnely: the armour decayed, the hor≈øes vnlu≈øty: the ≈øouldier impatient of the ≈øunne, the du≈øt, and the weather; and the more dull to ≈øu≈øtaine trauell, the apter to mutin. And be≈øide, the qualities of Caecina wrought no ≈ømall preiudice to the cau≈øe: his ambitious and populare proceeding, an old fault of his: a ≈øluggi≈øh and dull di≈øpo≈øition, lately ≈øprung vp: whether it were that too much fauour of fortune turned his edge & cau≈øed him to degenerat to riotous life, or that intending euen then trea≈øon in his minde, he thought it good pollicy by that meanes to weaken the valure and force of the army. Many haue beleeued that Caecinaes minde was ≈øhaken and altered fir≈øt by a practi≈øe ofBrother to Ve≈øpa≈øian and Prouo≈øt of Rome. Flauius Sabinus, Rubrius Gallus carying the me≈ø≈øage between them, and promi≈øing that Ve≈øpa≈øian ≈øhould ratify all couenants made and agreed in ca≈øe of reuolt: and withall he was put in remembrance of the hatred and emulation betweene Valens and him, and that ≈øeeing he had not like part in Vitellius, he ≈øhould doe wi≈øely to purcha≈øe credit and might with the new Prince. Caecina taking his leaue of Vitellius, and di≈ømi≈ø≈øed from his pre≈øence with great honour, ≈øent part of his hor≈øemen before to put them≈øelues in Cremona. Straight after the Vexillaries followed of theReade fifteenth, one of the foure Legions of lowe Germany. for the 14 was ≈øent away into Britanny p. 90. as enemy to Vitellius cau≈øe. fourteenth and of the ≈øixteenth Legion: then the fifth Legion and the eighteenth Legion: and la≈øtly the one and twentieth ≈øurnamed Rapax, and the fir≈øt called Italica with the Vexillaries of the three Britti≈øh Legions, and the choice of the Aides. When Caecina was gone, Fabius Valens wrote to the army, which before belonged to his charge, to ≈øtay for him in the way: that ≈øo it was agreed betweene him and Caecina: who being pre≈øent, and therefore of
greater autority, fal≈øely alledged, that vpon later adui≈øe that purpo≈øe was changed, to the end that re≈øi≈øtance might be made with the whole forces vnited again≈øt the enemies comming. So the Legions were commanded to make ≈øpeede to Cremona, and part to go to Ho≈øtilia. Caecina him≈øelfe turned out of the way to Rauenna, vpon pretence to giue direction to the nauy: and ≈øo to Padoua, where ≈øecretly the trea≈øon was contriued betweene Lucilius Ba≈ø≈øus and him. For Lucilius Ba≈ø≈øus after the captaine≈øhippe of a wing, being made Admirall of both the fleets at Rauenna and Mi≈øenum, becau≈øe he was not by and by created captaine of the Garde, reuenged his vniu≈øt anger with wicked di≈øloyalty: neither can it be certainly knowen, whether he drew Caecina into the action, or the ≈øame vile minde induced them both, as it happeneth often lewde per≈øons to be of like conditions. The hi≈øtories written of this warre, vnder Ve≈øpa≈øian and his children, haue deliuered fal≈øe and flattering cau≈øes, as that de≈øire of peace and loue of the common wealth moued them thereto. To me it ≈øeemeth, be≈øide the incon≈øtant di≈øpo≈øition of the men, and the ≈ømall account of their faith, which once being fal≈øed to Galba, afterward they neuer re≈øpected; that vpon emulation and enuy that others ≈øhould goe before them in the Princes fauour, they compa≈ø≈øed the de≈øtruction of the Prince him≈øelfe. When Caecina had ouertaken the Legions, hee ≈øought by ≈øundry ≈øuttle practi≈øes to weaken the good wils of the Centurions, and of the ≈øoldiers which were ob≈øtinately bent for Vitellius: Ba≈ø≈øus attempting the like founde not the like oppo≈øition, the nauy being ea≈øily induced to change their loialty, vpon the memory of their late ≈øeruice for Otho.

div.head: THE THIRD BOOKE OF THE HISTORIE OF CORNELIVS TACITVS.
I. The con≈øultation of the Flauian captaines, at Petouio in Pannonia, concerning the maner of proceeding in the warre. Sextilius Felix ≈øent into Noricum.

div.p:
WHEN Antonius had vnder≈øtanding hereof, he determined while≈øt the enemies were at di≈ø≈øen≈øion, and their forces not ioyned together, to v≈øe his aduantage and a≈ø≈øaile them, before either the Generals could ground their autority, or the ≈øouldiers

So with his whole ho≈øt he remoued from Verona, and the ≈øeconde night ≈øate downe at Bebriacum. The next day imploying his Legions in fortifying the campe, he ≈øent out his Auxiliary cohorts into the territory of Cremona, to the ende that the ≈øouldiers, vnder coulour of prouiding nece≈ø≈øaries, might be enured and fle≈øhedThat is, in ≈øpoiles growing by rea≈øon of ciuil warres in ciuill ≈øpoile. He to ≈øafe conduict the forragers aduanced him≈øelfe with foure thou≈øand hor≈øe eight miles forwarde from Bebriacum: and the skowts in the meane time, as the maner is, pricked on further. While≈øt Antonius was deliberating what was to be done, Arius Varus, de≈øirous to doe ≈øome piece of ≈øeruice, brake out with certaine of the forwarde≈øt hor≈øemen, & made the Vitelliani≈øts recule, and ≈ølew ≈øome few: for by and by more of their fellowes comming to helpe, fortune changed, and they that were mo≈øt forward before in pur≈øuing, were now left la≈øt in the flight. This ha≈øt was again≈øt Antonius will, who ≈øuppo≈øed the euent would be ≈øuch as it was: but ≈øeeing it coulde not bee vndone he encouraged his men to fight valiantly: and diuiding his troupes in two parts, left a lane in the midle to receiue in Varus with his hor≈øemen‚ñ™ worde al≈øo was ≈øent backe to the Legions to arme, and the alarme was giuen to tho≈øe that were forraging abroade, that euery man ≈øhould leaue of ≈øpoiling, and repaire with all ≈øpeede the next way to the fight. Nowe by this time Varus in a greate feare was retired within his owne troupes, and induced thither a generall terrour‚ñ™ the wounded and vnwounded were beaten in together, and greatly di≈øtre≈ø≈øed through their owne feare, and the ≈øtraytne≈ø≈øe
of the wayes. In all which confu≈øion and tumult Antonius omitted no parte either of a re≈øolute Generall, or valiant ≈øouldier, encouraging tho≈øe that were di≈ømayed, ≈øtaying them that ≈øhruncke; where mo≈øt neede was, whence any hope appeared, there bu≈øying him≈øelfe, with direction, hand and ≈øpeech, in the view of the enemie, in the ≈øight of his owne men, growing at the la≈øt to that heate, that with his launce he ranne thorow a guidon bearer who was fleeing away, and taking his guidon turned it again≈øt the face of the enemie: whereat for very ≈øhame there ≈øtayed about an hundreth hor≈øe. That which principally helped was the quality of the place, the Arctiore illic via: and yet a little before he ≈øaieth Angu≈øtijs viarum conflictabaÃÑtur. way being there ≈øomewhat narrow, and the bridge broken of the riuer that ranne behinde them, who≈øe vnknowen channell and ≈øteepe banckes ≈øtopped their further flight. That con≈øtraint or chance recouered the field that welny was lo≈øt. For knitting them≈øelues ≈øtrongly together, with thicke and clo≈øe rancks, they receyued the Vitellian ≈øouldiers comming on loo≈øely without any order. Which thing the le≈ø≈øe it was looked for, amazed them the more. Whereupon Antonius finding them yeelding pre≈ø≈øed the more in≈øtantly vpon them, ouerthrowing all that came in his way: and withall the re≈øt as their inclinations were, ≈øome fell to ≈øpoiling and catching, ≈øome to take armour and hor≈øes: euen they which before were broken, and ≈øcattered abroade in the fields, hearing the ioyfull crye of their fellowes, returned then backe to take part of the victory. About fower miles from Cremona, the en≈øeignes of two Legions, Rapax and Italica, appeared, hauing marched ≈øo farre vpon the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of their hor≈øemen at the beginning: but when fortune turned, they were ≈øo farre to ≈øeeke, as that they neither did open their ranckes, & receiue their di≈øtre≈ø≈øed fellowes within them, nor yet went forwarde to a≈ø≈øayle the enemie tired already with fightting and following ≈øo farre. As the Legions ≈øtoode wauering in termes of breaking, the Flauian hor≈øemen charged vppon them: and Vip≈øanius Me≈ø≈øalla the Tribune was at their heeles with the Moe≈øian Aides, who in militare renowne, albeit lately enrolled, were nothing inferiour to the Legionary ≈øouldiers. them le≈ø≈øe minde to re≈øi≈øt, and more hope to e≈øcape: neither did Antonius pre≈ø≈øe any further, con≈øidering the trauaile and woundes, which both his hor≈øemen and hor≈øes had taken, in ≈øo dangerous a skirmi≈øh, albeit the ende went on his ≈øide. Toward the ≈øhutting in of the euening the whole power of the Flauian army arriued: who a≈ø≈øoone as they troad among the heapes of dead bodies, in the fre≈øh ≈øteppes of ≈øo late a ≈ølaughter, as if the whole warre had bene ended, cryed to leade on out of hande to Cremona, and take by ≈øurrendre or force tho≈øe conquered per≈øons. The≈øe gay ≈øpeeches were in their mouthes and openly pretended, but ≈øecretely euery one ca≈øt thus with him≈øelfe; That a towne ≈øeated in the plaine might be wunne ea≈øily at a pu≈øh; that their courage would as well ≈øerue them to enter in the night, and their liberty to ≈øpoile would then be much greater: but if they attended till day, then would there come ≈øupplications and intreaties for peace, and ≈øo for their labour and hurts they ≈øhould cary away the vaine ≈ømokes of clemencie and glory, and ≈øuch other titulare matters, but the wealth and riches of the towne would cleaue to the captaines and Lieutenants fingers: that the ≈øpoile of a citty taken by force fell to the ≈øouldiers, but of a citty ≈øurrendred alwaies to the captaines alone. Hereupon the per≈øwa≈øions of the Tribunes & Centurions, as per≈øons ≈øu≈øpect, were reiected: and becau≈øe no mans ≈øpeech ≈øhould be heard, they ratled their weapons, threatening if no man would lead them be≈øide, to guide & conduct them≈øelues. Then Antonius in≈øinuating him≈øelfe among the common ≈øoldiers, after he had with the ≈øight of his per≈øon, & reuerence of his place, procured ≈øilence, prote≈øted vnto them, that his meaning was not in any ≈øort to defraude ≈øo well de≈øeruing ≈øoldiers, either of honour or reward‚ñ™ notwith≈øtanding the captaines and ≈øoldiers duties were of different nature: a ≈øouldier ought to be fierce and de≈øirous to fight, but in captaines a wary fore≈øight & deliberate kind of proceeding is rather commended‚ñ™ and more often times profiteth and helpeth hee by protracting, then venturing ra≈øhly. For his parte as he had to his power with weapons and hande furthered the victorie, ≈øo would hee likewi≈øe helpe now with direction and coun≈øaile, peculiare qualities to a Generall, and the place he ≈øu≈øtained. And ≈øurely if they li≈øt but a litle con≈øider, the dangerou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the enterpri≈øe was very apparent. it was now night, the ≈øituation of the towne was vnknowen,
within nothing but enemies, and euery cornerfit for an ambu≈øh: nay if the gates were wide open, yet were it not ≈øafe for to enter, no not in the day time, but vpon good di≈øcouery before hand, and a≈ø≈øurance that al coa≈øts were cleere. what? would they beginne an a≈ø≈øault when they could not di≈øcerne the be≈øt place of approach, nor the height of the walles, whether it were be≈øt to attempt them by di≈øcharging of ≈øhot a farre of, or by engins at hand, or by mine? then turning him≈øelfe to particulare per≈øons hee demaunded of them ≈øeuerally, whether they had brought their≈øecures & dolabrae. hatchets & axes with them, & all other tooles nece≈ø≈øary for an a≈ø≈øault: & when they denyed, What, quoth he, then, are any mens hands in the world of that force, and ≈øtrength to breake downe walles with iauelins and ≈øwords? what if it fall out that we mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity rai≈øe mounts, couer our ≈øelues with hurdles and frames of boarde? ≈øhall we not then be forced to ≈øtand like good ≈øilly fooles gazing & gaping at the height of their towers, & the ≈øtrength of their fortificatioÃÑs? nay rather let vs ≈øtay for one night, and fetch hither in the meane time our engins & in≈øtruments of battery, and ≈øo cary the victory ≈øurely before vs. And herewith he di≈øpatched thecal ‚Ä¢ ne ‚Ä¢ & ‚Ä¢ ixa. ≈øeruants & followers of the campe, and the fre≈øhe≈øt of his hor≈ømen to Bebriacum, to bring vittailes from thence, and all other nece≈ø≈øarie proui≈øion.

He wrote al≈øo letters vnto Ve≈øpa≈øian in a more hawty and arrogant ≈øtile, then be≈øeemed a ≈øubiect to his Prince, with ≈øecrete glances and nippes at Mutianus: That it was Antonius and no body els, who fir≈øt put in armes the Legions of Pannonia, and brought them into the field: that by his procurement and woorking the captaines of Moe≈øia were fir≈øt ≈øtirred vp to the warre: by his re≈øolutene≈ø≈øe the Alpes were pa≈ø≈øed, Italie po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and the ayde of the Rhoetians and German nations cut of: then, that Vitellius Legions being at di≈øcord and di≈øper≈øed the vantage was ≈øpyed, and they ouerthrowen fir≈øt by a furious charge of hor≈øemen, afterward by a power of footmen for a whole day & a night together; that was indeede the braue≈øt point of the ≈øeruice, and his only doing:
as for the mi≈øhappe of Cremona, it was a mi≈øchance of warre; and that the deciding of other ciuill di≈ø≈øen≈øions in former ages had co≈øt the common wealth much dearer, euen the ≈øubuer≈øion of manie great townes. that hee ≈øerued his Prince not with ≈øending of me≈ø≈øages and writing of letters, but with his per≈øon and weapon in hand: neither did he enuy or hinder their glory, that in the meane time had quieted Moe≈øia: they regarded the peace of Moe≈øia, and he the con≈øeruation and ≈øafety of Italie. by his per≈øwa≈øions France and Spaine, the mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øant parts of the Empire, were ioyned to the ≈øide: but all his paines and trauaile were in vaine, if they alone ≈øhould reape the rewards, which had no part in the perill. Mutianus was aduerti≈øed of all this proceeding, and there upon en≈øewed great enmitie, which Antonius pro≈øecuted ≈øimply and ≈øouldier like, but Mutianus clo≈øely, and therefore the more irreconcileably.

div.head: XI. ∆≤itellius proceedings and behauiour after the lo≈ø≈øe at Cremona. The reuolt of the nauie at Mi≈øenum.
div.p:
BVT Vitellius hauing receyued ≈øo great a blowe at Cremona, concealing the newes, and fooli≈øhly di≈ø≈øembling the matter, differred the remedies of his euils, not the euils them≈øelues. For if he would haue plainly confe≈ø≈øed it, and taken adui≈øe thereupon, hee had both hope and ≈øtrength inough and too much remayning: but whenas contrarily hee fayned that all went on his ≈øide, by that vntrueth hee marred his owne ca≈øe, and cut of from him≈øelfe all meanes of recouery. In his pre≈øence there was no mention of warre, but a wonderfull ≈øilence that way: in the citty all ≈øpeeches of it were forbidden, which cau≈øed the more: and they, which if it had bene lawfull would haue talked nothing but trueth, being re≈øtrayned gaue out much more then it was. The captaines al≈øo of the Flauian ≈øide helped to increa≈øe the fame, carying Vitellius ≈øpies, as they chanced to take them, round about the campe, to ≈øee and view the ≈øtrength of their victorious army, and ≈øo di≈ømi≈ø≈øing them backe to their ma≈øter. All which at their returne Vitellius, after ≈øecrete examination had, commanded to be made away. But aboue all other the Suetonius Othone. c. 10. Xiphilinus. p. 205. and after him Zonaras, reporteth this in the ≈øtory of Otho, in the former warre, with ≈øome ≈ømal differeÃÑce of circum≈øtances. con≈øtancy and re≈øolutenes of the Centurion Iulius Agre≈øtis was mo≈øt notable; who after much ≈øpeech tending to incite Vitellius to vertue
in vaine, at the length obtained that him≈øelfe might be ≈øent to view the forces of the enemie, and ≈øee what had pa≈ø≈øed at Cremona. For the performing whereof he ≈øought no corners, but addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe directly to Antonius, and openly profes≈øing what charge he had from his Prince, and what was his intent, he required hee might bee permitted to take a perfect ≈øuruey of all things. ≈øo ≈øome were ≈øent with him, which ≈øhewed him the place where the battaile was fought, the ruines of Cremona, the conquered Legions. Agre≈øtis went home againe, and making relation, whenas Vitellius would not beleeue his report, but charged him with vntrueth, and further that he was hired thereto: Seeing then (quoth Agre≈øtis) no meane proofe will ≈øerue, and neither my life nor my death can now ≈øtande you in any other ≈øteede, I will giue you an a≈ø≈øurance which you may beleeue; and ≈øo departing from him, he ≈øealed his ≈øayings voluntarily with his bloud. Some write that he was ≈ølaine by Vitellius commaundement, but of his fidelity and con≈øtancy they report the ≈øame. Now Vitellius beeing as it were awaked out of ≈øleepe, commaunded Iulius Pri≈øcus and Alphenus Varus with fourteene Praetorian cohorts, and all the wings of the hor≈øemen to keepe the ≈øtreits of the Apennine. after them followed a Legion of Seamen; a power both for number and goodne≈ø≈øe of men and hor≈øes ≈øufficient (if another had bene Generall) to make warre offen≈øiue, not onely to ≈øtande vppon their defence. The re≈øt of the cohorts were committed to Lucius Vitellius his brother to garde the citty withall. Him≈øelfe abating nothing of his wonted ryot, and ha≈øty through di≈øtru≈øt, hudled vp the election of officers, wherein he declared Con≈øuls forSuetonius Vitellio. c. 11. comitia in decem annos ordina vit ≈øe
que perpetuum, con≈øulem. many yeares to come. Moreouer newe treaties and more gracious were concluded with our allyes, and the right of Latium conferred vppon ≈øtrangers. To ≈øome hee relea≈øed their tributes, to others he granted immunities, without all care of po≈øterity mangling and mayming the Empire. But the common ≈øort accepted the≈øe fauours that ≈øeemed ≈øo great, and the fooli≈øhe≈øt bought them with money, which wi≈øe men accounted but voyde, beeing ≈øuch as could neither bee giuen nor taken with the ≈øafety of the ≈øtate. At the la≈øt through the in≈øtant reque≈øt of his armie lying in Meuania, with a great trayne of Senatours a≈ø≈øumed, partly vpon ≈øuite and mo≈øt vpon feare, he repayred to the campe irre≈øolute of him≈øelfe,
and obnoxious to vnfaithfull coun≈øailes. As he was ≈øpeaking to his ≈øouldiers in publike a≈ø≈øembly, it fell out ≈øo many vnlucky birdes to flye ouer his head (a mon≈øtrous matter) that the day was ouerca≈øt, as it were with a blacke cloude: and another no le≈ø≈øe ominous and of euill pre≈øage, that a bull which was appointed to be ≈øacrificed, brake away from the altars, ouerturned the furniture of the ceremonie, and was knocked downe farre of from the accu≈øtomed place. But the greate≈øt mon≈øter was Vitellius him≈øelfe, a Prince without skill in the profes≈øion of armes, and deuoyde of direction and coun≈øell, demanding eft≈øoones of others in what order to march, what diligence was requi≈øite in making di≈øcoueries, what meane was to be ob≈øerued in vrging, or delaying the warre, and vpon euery flying report apparently fearefull in countenance, and trembling in gate, and be≈øide all this mo≈øt commonly druncken. At the length growing weary of the campe, and vnder≈øtanding of the reuolt of the nauy at Mi≈øenum, hee returned to Rome, euer fearing mo≈øt the blowe that came la≈øt, and carele≈ø≈øe in the meane time of the mayne chance. For whereas it had bene a cour≈øe mo≈øt cleare in rea≈øon, and euident in ≈øight, to haue pa≈ø≈øed the Apennine with his army, which then was in hart and ≈øtrength, and ≈øo to haue a≈ø≈øayled the enemies almo≈øt con≈øumed with hunger and colde, he on the other ≈øide fell toTaking ≈øome with him to Rome, but principally in that he ≈øent away with his brother, as appeareth anone, ≈øix cohorts & fiue hundreth hor≈øe into Campania out of this army. di≈øper≈øing his forces, and ≈øo abandoned his be≈øt and faithfulle≈øt ≈øoldiers, whom he left thereby to the enemies mercy, and deliuered them as it were into their handes; contrary to the opinion of the mo≈øt expert Centurions, who di≈øliked greatly the di≈øuniting, and if their adui≈øe had beene asked, would haue tolde plainly their minde: but Vitellius inwarde≈øt frendes hindered them from acce≈ø≈øe, the Princes eares being ≈øo framed, that he accounted all ≈øharpe that was whole≈øome, & liked of nothing but that which was pre≈øently plea≈øant, and afterwards hurtfull. But the nauy at Mi≈øenum (≈øo much the audaciou≈øne≈ø≈øe euen of one ≈øingle man in ciuill di≈ø≈øen≈øions may work) was brought to reuolt by the meanes of Claudius Fauentinus, a Centurion ignominiou≈øly ca≈ø≈øed by Galba, who counterfayting letters from Ve≈øpa≈øian, with hope of reward induced them to change their allegeance. The Admirall thereof was Claudius Apollinaris, a man that neither con≈øtantly kept his fidelity, nor ≈øtoutly maintained his trea≈øon: and Apinius Tiro, who had bene Pretor, and
was then by chance at Minturnae, offred him≈øelfe for a head to them which reuolted; by who≈øe meanes the colonies and free townes were drawen to the ≈øide, the Puteolani ≈øhewing them≈øelues mo≈øt forward that way. But Capua on the other ≈øide, per≈øi≈øted firme to Vitellius: whereupon there pa≈ø≈øed, vnder coulour of the publicke cau≈øe, much priuate choler betweene the two townes. To the pacification of the≈øe troubles Vitellius cho≈øe out Claudius Iulianus (who had lately bene Admirall of the nauie at Mi≈øenum, and gouerned him≈øelfe in that charge with great mildne≈ø≈øe) as the meete≈øt man to appea≈øe the ≈øouldiers mindes; as≈øigning vnto him a power of one cittie-cohort, and theGladiatores fencers which were vnder his charge. A≈ø≈øoone as the campes approched the one to the other, Iulianus without any great ≈øtay turned to Ve≈øpa≈øians ≈øide, and ≈øo iointly they tooke Tarracian, a place of great ≈øtrength in regarde of the walles and ≈øituation, if the men within had bene faithfull and good. Vpon knowledge whereof Vitellius leauing part of his forces at Narnia, with the captaines of his Garde, ≈øent his brother Lucius Vitellius away with ≈øix cohorts and fiue hundreth hor≈øe, to manage the warre of Campania. Him≈øelfe beeing greatly perplexed in minde was yet ≈øomewhat reuiued with the earne≈øt goodwill of the ≈øoldiers, and clamours of the towne people requiring armour and weapons; whom being nought els but a cowardly companie, who≈øe boldne≈ø≈øe neuer went beyonde wordes, he called by the fal≈øe title of armies and Legions. At the per≈øwa≈øion of his freedmen (for of his frendes the greate≈øt men were lea≈øt tru≈øty) he commanded the tribes to be called, and ≈øware them which gaue in their names: too many pre≈øenting them≈øelues, he diuided the charge of the mu≈øter betweene the two Con≈øuls, and a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Senatours at a certaine number of bond-men, and quantity of ≈øiluer. The Gentlemen of Rome made offer both of their ≈øeruice and money, euen the Libertini requiring of their owne motion they might be admitted to doe al≈øo the like. This counterfayt forwardne≈ø≈øe made the offices, that were done for feare, be thought to proceede of goodwill. And indeede many pitied not ≈øo much the man, as the place he ≈øu≈øteined: & Vitellius him≈øelfe cea≈øed not by his countenance, ≈øpeech & teares to prouoke compa≈ø≈øion and pitty, promi≈øing largely, & (as the nature is of men in great feare) without mea≈øure. Moreouer he tooke then vpon him (which he
had refu≈øed before) the ≈øtile ofSuetonius Vitellio cap. 8. ≈øeemeth to ≈øay otherwi≈øe. cognomen Germanici delatum ab vniuer≈øis cupid√® recepit, Augu≈øti di≈øtulit, Cae≈øaris in perpetuum recu≈øavit. Cae≈øar, vppon ≈øome ≈øuper≈øtitious conceit of the name, and becau≈øe in a time of feare, the coun≈øailes of wi≈øe men, and prattlings of the people are heard & re≈øpected alike. But as all actions entred into vpon heate without con≈øideration are ≈øtronge≈øt in the beginning, and afterward fade and decay, ≈øo here the Senatours beganne by little and little to ≈øhrinke, and the Gentlemen likewi≈øe; at the fir≈øt with ≈øome re≈øpect and in Vitellius ab≈øence, but afterward more openly, being afrayde and pen≈øiue for the danger which was like to en≈øue; till in the ende Vitellius ≈øeeing the attempt not fea≈øible, for ≈øhame was contented, not to demande that he could not obtaine.

div.head: XII. The Flauiani≈øts pa≈ø≈øe ouer the Apennine. the ∆≤itelliani≈øts at Narnia yeeld them≈øelues. the death of Fabius ∆≤alens.
div.p:
AS the po≈ø≈øes≈øing of Meuania by the Vitelliani≈øts had wrought great terrour in Italie, ≈øeeing another warre as it were ≈øprung vp a fre≈øh by that meanes, ≈øo of the contrary ≈øide the departure of Vitellius in ≈øo fearefull maner procured great credit, and good to the Flauian cau≈øe. For pre≈øently thereupon the Samnites, and Peligni, and Mar≈øi reuolted; and vpon emulation that Campania had preuented them, to recompence their ≈ølackne≈ø≈øe, as men newly come to a new ma≈øter, ≈øhewed extreme diligence in furthering the ≈øeruice. But in pas≈øing the Apennine the armie by the fowlene≈ø≈øe of the winter weather was greatly di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, and marching with all liberty and quietnes could hardly wre≈øtle out of the ≈ønowe, ≈øo that it was cleare to be ≈øeene, what danger they mu≈øt needes haue ≈øu≈øtayned, if fortune, to which the Flauian captaines were more often beholding, then to their good guiding and skill, had not turned Vitellius backe home againe. In the mountaines Petilius Cerealis met them, who in clowni≈øh apparell through knowledge of the countrey had e≈øcaped Vitellius handes. Cerealis was of neare affinity with Ve≈øpa≈øian, & of ≈øome name for matters of warre, and therefore was a≈ø≈øumed among the Leaders. Many write that Flauius Sabinus and Domitian might al≈øo haue ea≈øily e≈øcaped, and certaine it is, that diuer≈øe me≈ø≈øengers ≈øent by Antonius by ≈øundry cunning ≈øleights came to their ≈øpeech, pointing the place, and offring them meanes for their ≈øafety: but Sabinus alleadged that his crazy body was
not to vndertake a matter of that paines, and ≈øuch an audacious attempt. Domitian would gladly haue ventured, but hee feared the keepers whom Vitellius had ≈øet about him, although they offred to accompany him in his e≈øcape, le≈øt peraduenture it had beene a ≈ønare to intrappe him: and indeede Vitellius him≈øelfe, in regarde of his owne kinsfolkes, intended no cruelty again≈øt Domitian. When the Flauian captaines were come to Car≈øula, they ≈øtaied there a fewe daies to repo≈øe their army, till their Legionary power ≈øhould ouertake them: and the place of the campe in it ≈øelfe was delitefull, with a large goodly pro≈øpect, and verie ≈øafe for the proui≈øion of vittailes, hauing ≈øo manie of the welthie≈øt citties, as it were ≈øtore hou≈øes behinde them. And be≈øides they were in ≈øome hope that the Vitelliani≈øts, which were not di≈øtant aboue tenne miles, would fall to ≈øome parle, and ≈øo from a parle to a reuolt: which thing the ≈øouldiers could not abide to heare of, but de≈øired an ende rather by conque≈øt, then by peace: euen their owne Legions they were vnwilling to ≈øtay for, loath to haue more fellowes in the ≈øpoile, when they needed none in the danger. But Antonius calling them publicklie together, ≈øhewed vnto them, that Vitellius had yet ≈øome forces remayning, wauering perhappes and vncon≈øtant if they might haue time to con≈øult, but of fierce ≈øtomacke if they were driuen to de≈øpaire: that the beginnings of ciuill warres were to bee permitted to fortunes deciding, but the accompli≈øhment of the victorie was to bee gouerned by rea≈øon and wi≈øedome: that the nauie of Mi≈øenum, and the mo≈øt flouri≈øhing countrey of Campania were alreadie reuolted, and there remayned nothing of al the world vnto Vitellius, ≈øaue onely ≈øo much as lay betweene Tarracina and Narnia: and ≈øurely they had wunne honour ≈øufficient in the battayle at Cremona, and blame too much by de≈øtroying the towne. therefore they ≈øhould not now de≈øire to take Rome, but rather to ≈øaue it: their rewarde would bee greater, and their glory mo≈øt great, if they wrought the ≈øafetie of the Senate and people of Rome without bloud≈øhed. With the≈øe and other like ≈øpeeches their mindes were mollified, and ≈øoone after the Legions came. The Vitellian cohortes terrified with the ≈øame of the armie ≈øo much increa≈øed, beganne to wauer, no man animating them to the warre, but manie to reuolt, who de≈øired to make a pre≈øent of their bandes and
cornets vnto the conquerour, to purcha≈øe fauour hereafter; and gaue al≈øo aduerti≈øement, that fa≈øt thereby at Interamna was a garri≈øon of fower hundreth hor≈øe. Whereupon immediately Varus was di≈øpatched with a band of men lightly appointed, and ≈ølewe ≈øome fewe that made re≈øi≈øtance: but the mo≈øt part laide downe their weapons, and yeelded them≈øelues to his mercy: ≈øome fled to the campe at Narnia, and filled all there full of feare and terror, extolling aboue trueth the forces and valour of the enemies, to dimini≈øh their owne di≈øhonour in lo≈øing their fort. Neither was there any puni≈øhment for offences among the Vitelliani≈øts; on the other ≈øide the rewardes were apparent of tho≈øe that reuolted: ≈øo that from thence foorth the contention was, who ≈øhould bee mo≈øt traitour, and daily ≈øome of the Tribunes and Centurions fled to the enemie: for the common ≈øouldier was ob≈øtinately bent for Vitellius, vntil Pri≈øcus and Alphenus Generalles for≈øaking the camp vpon feare, and returning to Vitellius, di≈øcharged the re≈øt from all blame of trea≈øon. About the ≈øame time Fabius Valens was put to death in the pri≈øon at Vrbine. His heade was openly ≈øhewed to the Vitellian cohortes to put them out of all hope: for before they beleeued that he was e≈øcaped into Germanie, and putting in armes both olde and newe ≈øouldiers there: but when they ≈øawe he was dead they beganne to de≈øpaire. The Flauian armie al≈øo tooke a wonderfull conceite as if his death were vndoubtedly the ende of the warre. Valens was borne at Anagnia, of a gentlemans hou≈øe, loo≈øe in conditions, and not without grace in ≈øeeking by wanton iea≈øtes the name of a plea≈øant conceite. In the games of Iuuenalia in Neroes time heeMimos actitavit. plaied a part, fir≈øt as it were by compul≈øion, then voluntarily, with more dexteritie then credit. Being created Lieutenant of a Legion hee both ≈øought to preferre Verginius to the Empire, and then to di≈øcredit him. Fonteius Capito his Lieutenant generall, either becau≈øe hee was entred into trea≈øon, or becau≈øe he could not induce him to trea≈øon, he murdred and made away. A traitour he was no doubt to Galba, and true to Vitellius, a vertue in him ≈øo much the more eminent, becau≈øe ≈øo many others were fal≈øe. Now the Vitellian ≈øouldiers ≈øeeing all their hope cut off, going to yeelde them≈øelues to the contrary part, euen in that al≈øo had a care of their honour, and came downe into the plaine vnder Narnia vnder their en≈øeignes and banners di≈øplaied: the Flauian army ≈øtoode armed
with their weapons bent, as in battell, in thicke ranckes along the way ≈øide. So the Vitelliani≈øts were receiued into the middle, and being ≈øo inclo≈øed about, Antonius intertained them with comfortable and gracious wordes, and appointed ≈øome of them to abide at Narnia, and ≈øome at Interamna, leauing ≈øome of his owne Legions withall, without mole≈øtation to them if they were quiet, and yet of force ≈øufficient to repre≈ø≈øe them if they rebelled.

div.head: XIII. Vitellius vpon compo≈øition with Flauius Sabinus Ve≈øpa≈øians brother offreth to re≈øigne vp the Empire. Sabinus by the ≈øouldiers is driuen into the Capitoll, and there be≈øieged. The Capitoll is burnt: Sabinus taken and ≈ølaine.
div.p:
DVRING their abode at Car≈øula, Antonius and Varus ≈øent continuall me≈ø≈øages vnto Vitellius, offring him, if he would ≈øurcea≈øe armes, and yeelde him≈øelfe and his children to Ve≈øpa≈øians mercy, life, money, and what ≈øecret place he would chu≈øe of Campania to retire him≈øelfe into: to the ≈øame effect Mutianus wrote al≈øo vnto him: and Vitellius oftentimes gaue eare thereunto, entring into ≈øpeech about the number of his ≈øeruants, and the choi≈øe of the place. So great a ≈øen≈øele≈øne≈ø≈øe had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed his minde, that if other men had not remembred, that he had beene once Prince, and therefore was not to looke for ≈øecurity in priuate e≈øtate, hee him≈øelfe would haue quickly forgotten it. But the principall men at Rome ≈øecretely incited Flauius Sabinus being Prouo≈øt of the citty, to put him≈øelfe into the cau≈øe, and vndertake part of the victory and of the honour: making remon≈øtrance vnto him, that the citty cohortes was his owne peculiare ≈øouldier, the cohortes of the Watchmen would que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe take his part, and their own retinue of bondmen ≈øhould bee at his di≈øpo≈øition, be≈øide the fortune of the ≈øide, and the ea≈øy cour≈øe of proceeding they finde, that be in traine of winning. that hee ≈øhould not yeelde the honour of the action to Antonius and Varus: that Vitellius had but fewe cohorts in number, and tho≈øe di≈øcouraged and trembling at the euil newes that came out of all quarters: the common people was fickle & changeable; & if Sabinus would pre≈øent him≈øelfe for a head, they would v≈øe the ≈øame flattering termes for Ve≈øpa≈øian, which now they did to the other. as for Vitellius hee was a man not able to gouerne him≈øelfe in pro≈øperity, much le≈ø≈øe ≈øufficient to wielde and winde out of his declining e≈øtate: that the honour of fini≈øhing
the warre would be his, who fir≈øt ≈øhould take po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of the citty; and ≈øo were it fit in al congruity, both for Sabinus to re≈øerue the Empire to his brother, and for Ve≈øpa≈øian to e≈øteeme of all other mens ≈øeruice ≈øecundarily to Sabinus.
