div.head: VII. Hordeonius Flaccus, Lieutenant generall of both Germanies, lying at Magontiacum, commaundeth Mummius Lupercus, vvho vvith tvvo Legions, the fift and the fifteenth, lodged at ∆≤etera, to goe forth again≈øt Ciuilis and the Batauians: but the Romans lo≈øt the battell, and fled backe into Vetera their standing campe.
div.p:
BVT Hordeonius Flaccus, who at the fir≈øt by conniuence nouri≈øhed Ciuilis attempts, now receiuing feareful aduerti≈øements, that theCa≈øtra ≈øc. cohortium. campes were ≈øurprized, the cohorts defeated & ≈ølaine, not one Roman left in the whole Batauian ilande, commanded
Mummius Lupercus the Lieutenant, who gouerned the ≈øtanding campe of two Legions, to goe foorth again≈øt the enimie. Lupercus taking the Legionaries about him, and the Vbians at hande, with certaine hor≈øemen of the Treueri not farre off, led them out in ha≈øte, taking al≈øo with him a wing of Batauians, which being long ≈øince ≈øecretely corrupted, notwith≈øtanding made ≈øhewe of fidelitie, to the ende that in the very in≈øtant of ioyning, betraying the Romans, they might ≈ølippe away with more dammage to the one, and bee better welcome to the other. Ciuilis placed rounde about him the en≈øeignes of the late taken cohortes, that his ≈øouldiers might bee encouraged in beholding the monument of their late glory, and the enemy di≈ømaied with the memory of their ouerthrow. Moreouer he cau≈øed his mother, and ≈øi≈øters, together with the wiues & young children of al his ≈øoldiers, to ≈øtand at their backs for an encouragement to the victory, or a ≈øhame if they happened to flee. In the ioyning of the two armies, the ≈øinging of their men, and howling of their women, farre exceeded and drowned the feeble ≈øhowte of our Legions and cohortes, and the Batauian wing fleeing to the enemy, and ≈øtraightway turning vpon vs, bared the left flancke of our battell: notwith≈øtanding the Legionary ≈øouldiers, as in a ca≈øe of ≈øuch danger, yet retained their weapons in their handes, and them≈øelues in array. The Aydes of the Vbians and Treueri ranne mo≈øt ≈øhamefully away, and brake euery where, which cha≈øe the Germans pur≈øued, & gaue by that meanes ley≈øure to our Legions to retire them≈øelues into their campe called Vetera. Claudius Labeo captaine of the Batauian wing, who had followed at home a contrary faction to Ciuilis, le≈øt that either his death ≈øhould offend the cuntrey, or his pre≈øence mini≈øter cau≈øe of di≈ø≈øen≈øion, was quietly ≈øent out of the way into Fri≈øia.

div.head: VIII. The eight Batauian cohorts, which had ≈øerued the Romans ≈øo long in Britannie, again≈øt Otho, and el≈øwhere, ≈øollicited by Ciuilis for≈øake Magontiacum, make their way at Bonna by the ≈øworde, and ≈øo ioine to Ciuilis.
div.p:
IN the meane ≈øea≈øon the me≈ø≈øenger ≈øent by Ciuilis to Magontiacum, to ≈øollicite the cohorts of Batauians & Caninefates, came
thither, and founde them in readine≈ø≈øe, by Vitellius commandement, to march toward Rome. Vpon that me≈ø≈øage receiued, forthwith they waxed prowde, and intolerable, crying out (or els refu≈øing to march) for their donatiue, for double wages, for an augmentation of the number of their hor≈øemen, things indeede promi≈øed by Vitellius, but demanded by them, not in hope to obtaine, but to picke an occa≈øion of mutinee: and Flaccus, yeelding to diuer≈øe of their demandes, gayned nought els, but that they more in≈øtantly craued tho≈øe things, which they knew hee could not but denie. So ≈øetting Flaccus at naught they tooke vp their en≈øignes, and marched towarde lowe Germanie, to ioyne them≈øelues with Ciuilis. Hordeonius calling the Tribunes and Centurions al≈øo to councell, debated the matter, whether he ≈øhould by maine ≈øtrength ≈øeeke to enforce them, which ≈øo contemptuou≈øly brake away: anone, partly of his owne cowardlie nature, partly through the timorou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the officers, who tru≈øted neither the faith of their Aides, nor the force of theirAt Magontiacum then with Hordeonius were abiding two Legions; quartae, & duodevice≈øima ali√¢s ducetvice≈øim ‚Ä¢ . Legions, being gathered in ha≈øt of men vnskilfull in ≈øeruice, he re≈øolued to keepe his ≈øoldiers within the trenches, and let the Batauians pa≈ø≈øe. Afterwarde, repenting him≈øelfe of that re≈øolution, they al≈øo blaming it, which were chiefe autours thereof, as if he ment to pur≈øue them, he wrote to Herennius Gallus gouernour of Bonna, and Lieutenant of the fir≈øt Legion, which wintered there, that he ≈øhould ≈øtoppe the Batauians from pa≈ø≈øage, promi≈øing that he, with his whole power, would not faile to be on their backes. And ≈øo verily they might haue beene defeated and ≈ølaine, if Hordeonius of the one ≈øide, and Gallus of the other, had brought forward their power, and enclo≈øed them in behinde and before: but Flaccus changed his purpo≈øe againe, and in other letters of later date willed Gallus, not to ≈øtaye their pa≈ø≈øage. Whereupon ≈øu≈øpicion aro≈øe, that the Lieutenaunts of ≈øet purpo≈øe ≈øtirred vp and fo≈øtered the≈øe warres; yea all the mi≈øchieffes, which either had chanced alreadie, or were feared hereafter, were imputed, not to the cowardline≈ø≈øe of the ≈øouldier, or ≈øtrength of the enemie, but onely to the fraude and fal≈øehoode of the Leaders. When the Batauians drew neare to the campe at Bonna, they ≈øent before certaine me≈ø≈øengers, to declare to Herennius Gallus the intention of the cohorts: that their meaning was not to make warre with
the Romans, in who≈øe behalfe they had ≈øo oft borne armes; but fora≈ømuch as they were wearied with along and fruitle≈ø≈øe ≈øeruice, their de≈øire was, quietly to liue at home in their cuntrey. And therefore, if no man made oppo≈øition, their pa≈ø≈øage ≈øhould be harmele≈ø≈øe: but if any ho≈øtility were offred, they would make their way with the ≈øworde. While≈øt the Lieutenant ≈øtoode deuided in minde what to doe, his ≈øoldiers vrged him to put it to the fortune of a field. There were in his campe three thou≈øandWhereas the ful and iu≈øt nuÃÑ ber of a Legion ≈øhould bee 6000. or 5000. at the lea≈øt. Legionary ≈øoldiers, and certaine tumultuary cohorts of Belgians, and withal a number of pezants, and followers of the campe, braue men before the danger approche, in the danger but cowards. Out they i≈ø≈øue at all the gates of the campe to enclo≈øe the Batauians, whom they knew to be farre inferiour in number. The Batauians, mindfull of their olde order in ≈øeruice, ≈øet them≈øelues in array in pointed battels, ≈øtanding on euery ≈øide clo≈øe together, & hauing their front, their flanckes, and their backe ≈øurely garded, and ≈øo with great facility brake thorow our thinne companies. The Belgians fir≈øt gaue ground, and then our Legionaries were beaten backe, and ranne for feare toward the trenches, and gates of the campe. There the mo≈øt ≈ølaughter was committed: the fo≈ø≈øes were filled vp with dead bodies, and many dyed in the throng, by tumbling one ouer another, and running vpon their own weapons, a≈øwell as ≈ølaine by the enemie. After this victory the Batauians went forward, leauing Coleyn of the right hand, & attempted no act of ho≈øtility in the re≈øt of their iourney, but excu≈øing the battaile at Bonna as a thing done by con≈øtraint, and for their owne ≈øafety, whenas they intreated for peace and it would not be granted.

Their an≈øwere

The Bructeri and Teucteri a≈ø≈øociate them≈øelues, and me≈ø≈øengers were ≈øent into Germanie, who ray≈øed the whole cuntrey, ≈øome to winne honour, and ≈øome to gaine ≈øpoile. Ciuilis led the middle battell him≈øelfe, wherein was the flower and ≈øtrength of Batauia: and on both ≈øides of the Rhene, to the ende the ≈øight of his armie might ≈øtrike in the greater terrour, he cau≈øed the regiments of the Germans to march, the hor≈øemen galloping about the fields: and withall the ≈øhippes were brought vp the ≈øtreame. So on the one hande the en≈øignes of the oldeTo wit, the Batavians. cohorts, on the other the pictures and images of wilde bea≈øts taken out of their woods and con≈øecrated groues, according as euery nation v≈øeth to beare in the field, amazed our men, and terrifyed them doubly, with the ≈øhewe both of an externall, and ciuill warre. Moreouer the great compa≈ø≈øe of the trench made the attempt of the be≈øiegers more fea≈øable and increa≈øed their hope. Now to the ende, that being ≈øeuered in place, the prowe≈ø≈øe of ech nation might more di≈øtinctly appeare, and be ≈øeene, the Batauians, and the Germans which dwelt beyonde the Rhene, tooke ≈øtanding ech by them≈øelues, and began to dart at our men a farre of. But whenas they ≈øawe mo≈øt of their weapons ≈øticking in vaine in the turrets, and pinnacles of the walles, and many of them≈øelues wounded with ≈øtones throwen from aboue on their heads, leauing that kinde of oppugnation, they ≈øodainly with great force, and outcry a≈ø≈øayed to ≈øcale the trenches, the mo≈øt part by ≈øetting vp ladders, others climing ouer the heads of their fellowes vpon a target fence. And as ≈øome were now clamering vp, they were beaten downe headlong with ≈øwordes and pu≈øh of pike, and ≈øo with clubbes, and dartes ouerwhelmed, being men otherwi≈øe hoat in the beginning, and too too couragious when fortune fauoureth, but then for de≈øire of pray they tolerated all hardne≈ø≈øe al≈øo: yea and that which with them is vnu≈øuall, they endeuoured to prooue with engins, whereof they had of them≈øelues neither experience nor skill, onely ≈øome fugitiues and captiues taught them to frame timberin med ‚Ä¢ m ‚Ä¢ on als. in maner of a bridge, and to driue it forward on wheeles, whereon certaine ≈øtanding aboue might skirmi≈øh with them on the walles, as it were from a mount, and others within ≈øecretely vndermine the foundations. div.head: X. Hordeonius di≈øpatching ∆≤ocula before remooueth from Magontiacum with his power to Bonna: and thence to Coleyn. where he re≈øigneth the execution of his charge to Vocula: following notwith≈øtanding the armie from thence to Noue≈øium, where, as it ≈øeemeth, he staied till his death. At Noue≈øium Gallus is ioyned in commi≈øsion with ∆≤ocula: and ≈øo they remoued forward to Gelduba‚ñ™ where being encamped, Vocula wasteth the Gugerni, and Gallus is beaten by the Germans.
div.p:
IN the meane time Flaccus, hauing vnder≈øtoode of the ≈øiege of Vetera, and ≈øent into France to leuy Aides, ≈øelected out of his Legions a company of cho≈øen men, and committed them to the leading of Dillius Vocula, Lieutenant of the eighteenth Legion, willing him to ha≈øten, and make all po≈øsible ≈øpeede along the bancke of the riuer; him≈øelfe followed ≈ølowly, and drooping for feare, being mortally hated of his ≈øouldiers. For they openly charged him, that hee had ≈øuffred wilfully to ≈øcape from Magontiacum the cohortes of the Batauians, or rather purpo≈øelie ≈øent them away: that Ciuilis rebellious attempts were by his conniuence fo≈øtered, and by his meanes the Germans called to the party‚ñ™ that neither Antonius Primus, nor Mutianus, had ≈øo ≈øtrengthened Ve≈øpa≈øians ≈øide, as Flaccus by this kinde of di≈ø≈øembling dealing: for open enemies and armes might openly and with armes be repelled, but fraude and deceite were matters hardly e≈øpied, & therefore could not be auoided‚ñ™ that Ciuilis ≈øtoode in the fielde embattelled again≈øt them, but Hordeonius out of his bed chamber gaue order, and directed as was mo≈øt for the enemies behoofe: and why then ≈øhould ≈øo many armed companies of valiant ≈øouldiers bee gouerned by a ≈øicke and ≈øeely olde man? nay why ≈øhould they not rather di≈øpatch ≈øuch a traitour, and free their fortune and vertue from the ill chance of ≈øo vnlucky a leader? As they were in the≈øe ≈øpeeches one with another, letters came from Ve≈øpa≈øian which incen≈øed them more, the which Flaccus, becau≈øe hee could not conceale, cau≈øed openly to bee red before the a≈ø≈øembly, and ≈øent the bringers thereof bounde to Vitellius. By this meanes the ≈øouldiers mindes were ≈øomewhat appea≈øed: and ≈øo they came to Bonna the ≈øtanding campe of the fir≈øt Legion: the ≈øouldiers whereof were more di≈øplea≈øed
with Flaccus then the other: laying the fault of their late ouerthrowe wholly vpon him: auerring that they at his commaundement marched forth again≈øt the Batauians, a≈ø≈øuring them≈øelues, vpon his promi≈øe, that his Legions from Magontiacum ≈øhould a≈ø≈øayle them behinde; and ≈øo no ≈øupply comming from thence, they lo≈øt their liues through his trea≈øon: that the≈øe matters had neuer beene notified to the re≈øt of the armies, nor to the Prince, or els by the helpe and a≈øsi≈øtance of ≈øo many cuntreies this ≈øodaine rebellion might haue beene quenched in the beginning. Whereupon Hordeonius cau≈øed the coppies of all the letters, which he had ≈øent into France, Britannie and Spaine, reque≈øting their helpe, to be red to the army, and beganne a very ill example, that all letters ≈øent from abroade ≈øhould be deliuered to the ≈øtanderd-bearers of the Legions, who red them to the ≈øouldiers, before they came to the Generals hande. Then he commanded one of the mo≈øt factious to be apprehended and bound, rather to put his right in vre, then becau≈øe the fault was but of one man alone: and ≈øo heTaking along with him the fir≈øt Legion, or a great part thereof, as it doeth appear. p. 172. &c. remoued with his army from Bonna to Coleyn, where many Aydes re≈øorted vnto him of the French nation, which at the fir≈øt with all their power a≈øsi≈øted the Romans, till afterwards ≈øeeing the Germans preuaile, many of them tooke armes again≈øt vs in hope of freedome, and that point attained, for de≈øire of ≈øouerainty. But the wrath of the Legions ≈øtil increa≈øed, neither could one ≈øouldiers impri≈øonment terrifie them: nay euen the party impri≈øonned impeached the Generall of trea≈øon; alleadging that he had beene me≈ø≈øenger betweene Ciuilis and him, and therefore a colour was ≈øought to make him away, le≈øt he ≈øhould declare, and te≈øtifie the trueth. Then Vocula, with maruelous ≈øtoutne≈ø≈øe a≈øcending into the Tribunal, commanded the ≈øouldier, as he exclamed and cried, to be apprehended, and caried away to execution: which thing ≈øo terrified the bad and ≈øeditious, that the ≈øounder ≈øort without impeachment fulfilled his commaundement, and anone by common con≈øent they demanded Vocula to bee their Generall: which place Flaccus willingly re≈øigned vnto him. But their minds were already mutinou≈øly affected, and many new occa≈øions of more rage were pre≈øented; as want of pay, & proui≈øion of corne; And yet not ten lines before he writeth, affluentibus auxilijs Gallorum, quae prim√≤ rem Romanam enix√® iuvabant. France refu≈øing to yeelde ≈øouldiers and tributes; the Rhene al≈øo by rea≈øon of drought vnu≈øuall in that cuntrey hardly able to beare any ve≈ø≈øell; ≈øcarcity of vittailes; garri≈øons of men
placed along the bancke to keepe the Germans from pa≈øsing the riuer; and ≈øo le≈ø≈øe corne, and more men to con≈øume it. Among the ignorant and ≈øimpler ≈øort the lowne≈ø≈øe of the water was held for a prodigious matter, as if the riuers al≈øo, and the ancient defences of the Empire had now for≈øaken vs, & that which in peaceable times would haue beene counted chance, or proceeding of naturall cau≈øes, at that time was called a fatall matter, and gods indignation and wrath. At Noue≈øium they a≈ø≈øumed the ≈øixteenth Legion; and Herennius Gallus Lieutenant of the fir≈øt Legion was ioyned with Vocula in part of the charge: yet dur≈øt they not goe to finde the enemy, but encamped them≈øelues at a place called Gelduba. There they trained, and practi≈øed their ≈øoldiers in ordering of battels, in fortifyng, entrenching, and other militare exerci≈øes. And to the ende that they might by booties and ≈øpoiles take courage and hart, Vocula led forth part of his army into the cuntrey of the Gugerni adioyning, who had allyed them≈øelues with Ciuilis: part remained behinde with Herennius Gallus. And as by chance, not farre from the campe, a barge loaden with corn, was runne vpon a ≈øhelfe, the Germans e≈øpying it laboured to draw it to their ≈øide of the water; which Gallus would not endure, but ≈øent a cohort to the reskew: the Germans al≈øo increa≈øed their number, and ≈øo by little and little, ≈øupply re≈øorting on both ≈øides, a battaile was fought: wherein the Germans, after the ≈ølaughter of many of our men, by force haled the boate away. Our ≈øouldiers, being thus put to the wor≈øe, according to their cu≈øtome there, blamed not their owne cowardline≈ø≈øe, but the trea≈øon of the Lieutenant, whom they drew out of his tent, tare his clothes, and bet his body, commanding him to tell vpon what price, and with what complices he had thus betrayed the army. ButWho, as it ≈øeemes, ≈øtayed behind at Noue≈øium. Hordeonius was charged with the whole enuy of the fact; him they termed the contriuer of the mi≈øchiefe, Gallus onely the in≈øtrument; till at length Gallus, being terrified with their threatning of his de≈øtruction, to ≈øaue his owne life, was content to charge Hordeonius al≈øo with trea≈øon. Then was he put in bandes, and afterwardes, at the returne of Vocula loo≈øed, who the next day following put to death the autors of the ≈øturre. So ≈øtrange diuer≈øity there was in that army, both licentiou≈øly to commit all enormities, and patiently to abide all correction. The Picentine wing could not endure the ioy, and in≈øulting of the people, but neglecting as well the threates as the promi≈øes of Sanctus, turned to Magontiacum; and meeting by chaunce in the waye Longinus the murtherer of Vocula with their darts ≈ølewe him for a beginning of future amendes. The Legions went forwarde in

div.head: XXV. An emba≈ø≈øage of the Tencterians to them of Coleyn. Coleyn yeeldeth to Ciuilis and ∆≤elleda vpon rea≈øonable compo≈øition.
div.p:
CIVILIS and Clas≈øicus puffed vp with pro≈øperous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe made a que≈øtion, whether they ≈øhould permit the citty of Coleyn to be ≈øacked by their ≈øouldiers. Their naturall inclination to cruelty and couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe drew them that way, but the pollicie of warre was again≈øt it, and e≈øpeciallie the opinion of clemencie needfull in tho≈øe which are to founde a newe Empire: the remembrance al≈øo of a priuate benefite made Ciuilis more tractable towarde them, becau≈øe in the very beginning of the troubles taking his ≈øonne in their towne they committed him to honourable cu≈øtodie. Notwith≈øtanding the nations beyond the Rhene enuyed the riches, and growing of the citty, and iudged there could be no ende of warre, vnle≈ø≈øe that towne were either made a common habitation for all Germans indifferently, or els razed to the ground, and ≈øo the Vbij al≈øo di≈øper≈øed. Wherefore the Tencteri, a people onely ≈øeuered from them by the riuer, ≈øent an emba≈ø≈øage, with in≈øtruction to declare their charge in the common councell of Coleyn, which one of the mo≈øt imperious among the emba≈ø≈øadours vttered in this peremptory maner. "We thanke our gods and yours, and Mars chieffe of all gods, that you are returned into the corps and communitie, and name of Germanie; and wee reioyce for your ≈øakes, that you ≈øhall at length liue as freemen among freemen. For hitherto the Romans haue ≈øhut both water and lande, and in a maner the very heauen it ≈øelfe betweene you and vs to hinder our conferring and meeting, or els which is more contumelious to martiall men, that we ≈øhould neuer haue acce≈ø≈øe to your cittie but vnarmed, and naked almo≈øt and that garded and paying a toll. But now, to the ende that this mutuall league of allyance and frend≈øhippe may ≈øtande and continue for euer, wee require of you to pull downe the walles of your towne, the bulwarkes of your bondage: for euen wilde bea≈øts ≈øhut vp forget their accu≈øtomed valour and vertue. Next we require you to kill all the Romans within your territorie: liberty and Lordes
cannot dwell together. Then to bring out all their goods and diuide them in common, that no man ≈øhould hide any thing, or ≈øeeke to ≈øeuer his cau≈øe from the re≈øt. Moreouer that it may be indifferent both for vs and you, as it was in times pa≈øt to our fathers, to conuer≈øe and inhabite vpon both ≈øides of the riuer. As nature hath communicated the day and the night to all men, ≈øo hath ≈øhe layed open all landes of the world to valiant mindes. Re≈øume your ancient cu≈øtomes and lawes, laying a≈øide all your effeminate plea≈øures, by which meanes, more then with armes the Romans ≈øubdue nations and cuntreyes. So ≈øhall you be a people vncorrupt, without admixtion of forreyne maners or bloud: ≈øo ≈øhall you forget ≈øeruitude, and either liue in liberty, or be lordes ouer others. The Agrippinen≈øes taking a time to deliberate: ≈øeeing neither future feares would permit them to yeelde to the conditions, nor their pre≈øent e≈øtate playnly to refu≈øe them, made an≈øwere in this maner. "We haue taken, you ≈øee, the fir≈øt opportunitie of recouering our liberty, perchance with more ha≈øt then good ≈øpeede, that we might bee ioyned with you, and the re≈øt of the Germans our kin≈ømen: but ≈øeeing the Roman armies doe gather of all ≈øides again≈øt vs, it is meeter and ≈øafer to ≈øtrengthen, then to pull downe the walles of our cittie. As for ≈øtrangers, Italians or other, which liued among≈øt vs, eyther they are ≈ølaine in the warres, or fled home to their cuntreyes. To them which be ancient inhabitants among≈øt vs, and are lincked with vs in mariage, and to their of ≈øpring, this cuntrey is their owne natiue ≈øoile: neither doe we thinke you ≈øo vnrea≈øonable as to wi≈øh vs to kill our parents, our brethren, or children. For taxe and tallage we acquite and di≈øcharge you for euer: you ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe and repa≈ø≈øe without all impeachement, but onelie in the day time, and vnarmed, till our rawe and newe amitie bee ioyned, and confirmed by continuance and cu≈øtome. Ciuilis and Velleda ≈øhall bee arbiters: to their knowledge we referre the cau≈øe, and the conclu≈øion of the whole treaty. The Tencteri being thus in parte pacified, emba≈ø≈øadours were ≈øent to Ciuilis and Velleda with pre≈øents, who obtained all things as they of Coleyn de≈øired: onely they were not admitted to haue acce≈ø≈øe, or ≈øpeech with Velleda, nor ≈øuffred to ≈øee her, for more keeping of ≈øtate, and to maintaine a more reuerende conceyt in the
harts of the people. She was lodged in a high tower, and one of her kinred appointed to cary as from a godde≈ø≈øe hir oracles and an≈øweres.

div.head: XXVI. The Betha≈øij, Tungri and Neruij yeeld to Ciuilis.
div.p: CIVILIS thus ≈øtrengthened with new increa≈øe of confederats, re≈øolued to a≈ø≈øociate the citties adioyning, or to warre again≈øt them if they re≈øi≈øted. So he tooke in the Sunici, and compo≈øed their able men into cohorts: but as he purpo≈øed to haue pa≈ø≈øed further, Claudius Labeo with a rawe companie of Betha≈øij, Tungri, and Neruij, hauing ≈øey≈øed vpon the bridge of the Mo≈øe, and tru≈øting to the aduantage of the place, oppo≈øed him≈øelfe and ≈øtopped his pa≈ø≈øage. The euent of the skirmi≈øh was doubtfull in the ≈øtraytes, till the Germans ≈øwimming ouer the riuer came vpon Labeoes backe: and withall Ciuilis, whether vpon a bolde venture, or vpon a ≈øet match, ru≈øhed into the midde≈øt of the Tungri, and with a lowde voice prote≈øted, that the warre was not vndertaken to that ende, that the Batauians and Treueri ≈øhould be ≈øoueraine lordes ouer all other nations: Farre be all ≈øuch arrogancie (quoth he) from our thought: onelie receyue vs as your good frendes and allies. Lo here for my part I commit my ≈øelfe to your handes, employ mee as you li≈øt, either for a captaine or a common ≈øouldier. The common people was much mooued at the≈øe wordes, and put vp their ≈øwordes, and Campanus and Iuuenalis chieffe men of the Tungrians yeelded the whole nation vnto him: Labeo before he was compa≈ø≈øed in fled away. The Betha≈øij al≈øo and Neruij yeelded them≈øelues: whom Ciuilis adioyning to his power became very pui≈ø≈øant and ≈øtrong, all the citties either fearing, or fauouring him voluntarily.

div.head: XXVII. Julius Sabinus with his Lingones giueth battaile to the Sequani, and is ouerthrowen.
div.p:
IN the meane ≈øea≈øon Iulius Sabinus, breaking downe the monuments and recordes of the Roman alliance, tooke vpon him the ≈øtile & title of Cae≈øar, & led after him a huge and rude company of his cuntrey folkes, the Lingones, again≈øt the Sequani, a ≈øtate bordering vpoÃÑ them, & faithfull to vs Neither did the Sequani refu≈øe to wage battaile; wherein fortune fauoured the better ≈øide, & the

Sabinus as ra≈øhly hee enterpri≈øed to giue battaile without due circum≈øpection, ≈øo without feare of ≈øhame he ranne cowardly away: and to rai≈øe a rumour that he was dead, he ≈øet on fire the hou≈øe, into which he was knowen to haue fled, & there was ≈øuppo≈øed voluntarily to haue ended his life. div.head: XXVIII. A Diete of the citties of France ≈øummoned at Rheyms. The preparations at Rome for the warre again≈øt the Batauians, Treueri, and Lingones. The Diete at Rheyms re≈øolueth vpon peace, notwith≈øtanding the emba≈ø≈øage of the Treueri and Lingones, and the allegations of Tullius ∆≤alentinus to the contrary.
div.p:
THIS ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of the Sequani rebated and ≈øtayed the violent cour≈øe of the warre. The citties beganne to con≈øider better of matters, and to remember their couenants and leagues with the Romans, at the motion principally of the Remi, who ≈øending me≈ø≈øengers throughout France ≈øummoned a Diete, to deliberate what cour≈øe they ≈øhould take, keep peace or ≈øeeke liberty. Al the≈øe things reported at Rome to the wor≈øe, troubled Mutianus, le≈øt the captaines whom he had cho≈øen, Annius Gallus and Petilius Jo≈øephus
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . 7. c. 11. differeth from Tacitus in ≈øome little circum≈øtances, and no doubt erreth: as that Cerealis,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ was ≈øent Lieutenant in to Britanny ( „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ) and in his way finding the Germans and French reuolted, compo≈øed the matter, Cerealis, albeit excellent men, ≈øhould hardly be able to wade thorow ≈øo mighty a warre. Neither was it expedient to leaue the citty without a gouernour and head, and yet not in Domitians hande, who≈øe wilde and vnbridled affections were greatly feared: e≈øpecially Antonius Primus, and Arrius Varus, as before wee haue ≈øhewed, beeing ≈øu≈øpected not fully to fauour the ≈øtate. Moreouer Varus was captaine of the Garde and ≈øtrong, as hauing ≈øo many ≈øouldiers at commandement. Therefore Mutianus before his departure di≈øplaced him from the roome, and le≈øt he ≈øhould be di≈øcontent altogether, made him chieffe officer for the proui≈øion of corne: and to pacify the minde of Domitian, that bare ≈øome good will vnto Varus, he ≈øet in his place ouer the Garde Aretinus Clemens, one nearely allyed to the hou≈øe of Ve≈øpa≈øian, and dearely beloued of Domitian; alleaging that his
father had worthily perfourmed the ≈øame place vnder Caius the Emperour. The name was acceptable to the ≈øouldiers, and the man, though a Senatour by calling, was thought ≈øufficient to di≈øcharge both the roomes. The greate≈øt men of the Citty were willed to prouide for the viage of France: ≈øome others were taken in by e≈øpeciall ≈øuite.Suet. Domic. c. 2. expeditioneÃÑ quo
que in GalliaÃÑ Germania≈ø

que nece≈ø≈øariaÃÑ, & di≈ø≈øuadentibus paternis amicis, inchoavie (Domitianus) tantum vt fratri ≈øe, & operibus, & dignatione, adaequaret. Domitian and Mutianus both of them prepared for the iourney, but not both minded alike: Domitian ha≈øtening forward vpon hope, and young bloud: Mutianus ≈øeeking delayes to retaine the fiercene≈ø≈øe of Domitian, le≈øt if he put him≈øelfe in po≈ø≈øes≈øion of an armie, through the heate of youth and ill coun≈øellours, he ≈øhould di≈øturbe both the peace and the warre. The ≈øixth andVide annot. 5. eightth of the victorious Legions, of the Vitelliani≈øts the one and twentieth, the ≈øecond of the lately enrolled, wereSome before Cerealis, and ≈øome after him, as it appeareth in this booke & the next. conducted part ouer the Penin and Cottian Alpes, part ouer the Graian: & more ouer the fourteenth Legion was ≈øent for out of Britannie, the ≈øixth and tenth out of Spaine. Now the citties of France partly vpon the fame of the ho≈øt approching, and partly of their owne di≈øpo≈øition inclining to the milder cour≈øe, met in coun≈øell at Rheyms, where an emba≈ø≈øage of the Treueri attended, whereof Tullius Valentinus was the chieffe man, a principall firebrande of the warre: who with a premeditate oration applyed to the Romans all tho≈øe obiections, wherewith mighty monarchies are v≈øually charged, ≈øparing no ≈øpite of wordes, nor art to aggrauate matters again≈øt them; a factious per≈øon and apt to ≈øtirre troubles, and willingly heard of the multitude, by rea≈øon of his eloquence ≈øuch as it was. But Iulius Au≈øpex, one of the noblemen of Rheims, di≈øcour≈øing of the pui≈ø≈øance of the Roman power, & the great commodities of peace, and affirming that warre might be commenced by cowards, but mu≈øt be fought with the hazard of the mo≈øt valiant men; & that euen now the Roman Legions were vpon their backs, by this graue ≈øpeech ≈øtayed them all: the wi≈øer ≈øort with re≈øpect of duety and faith, the younger of danger and feare. And ≈øo they commended the courage of Valentinus, but followed the coun≈øayle of Au≈øpex. It is certaine that the Treueri and Lingones had the wor≈øe audience in France, becau≈øe in the commotion of Vindex they had ≈øided them≈øelues with Virginius. Many were di≈øcouraged by rea≈øon of the emulation that would en≈øue betweene the prouinces; what ≈øhould be the head of the warre, fromVnde ius au≈øpicium
que peteretur. whence
≈øhould lawe and ≈øouerainty be deriued; and if they did conquere which ≈øhould be the ≈øeat-towne of the Empire. They were not yet conquerours, & yet were they at di≈øcorde brawling about the pre≈øeance: ≈øome alleaging their treaties and ancient leagues, ≈øome their riches and pre≈øent ≈øtrength, & ≈øome their antiquitie. Whereupon the whole councell dete≈øting the future confu≈øion, affirmed and ratifyed the pre≈øent e≈øtate. Letters al≈øo were writen vnto the Treueri in the name of the common councell of France to de≈øi≈øt from armes, while≈øt pardon might be ea≈øily obtained, & many would become ≈øuters in their behalfe if they repented. But Valentinus refu≈øed the curte≈øie, and at his returne ≈øtopped the eares of his citty again≈øt this good motion, being a man rather plentifull in orations and ≈øpeeches, then carefull for other proui≈øion of warre.

div.head: XXIX. The one and twentieth Legion ≈øurnamed Rapax commeth into Germanie. Sextilius Felix with his cohorts ouerthroweth Tutor and the Treueri. Valentinus returning from the Diete stirreth vp the warre againe. The two Legions tran≈øported from Noue≈øium and Bonna to Triers depart to the Mediomatrici.
div.p:
IN like maner neither did the Treueri, nor Lingones, nor the re≈øt of the ≈øtates that reuolted, cary them≈øelues as the weight of the cau≈øe and the danger required: euen the captaines them≈øelues conferred not coun≈øailes together. But Ciuilis wandred about the wildes of Belgium to catch Claudius Labeo, or els to cha≈øe him out of the cuntrey: Clas≈øicus lay for the mo≈øt part idle and lazy, and as it were tooke the fruition of his ≈øuppo≈øedly gotten kingdome. Tutor al≈øo ≈ølacked to make him≈øelfe ≈øtrong vpon the vpper bancke of the riuer, and with garri≈øon to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the pa≈ø≈øages and heights of the Alpes, while≈øt in the meane time the one and twentieth Legion brake in from Vindoni≈ø≈øa, and Sextilius Felix, with the Auxiliary cohorts by the way of Rhoetia: vnto whom a wing of hor≈øemen called Singulares (who marching at the fir≈øt by Vitellius appointmeÃÑt toward Italie reuolted afterward to Ve≈øpa≈øian) adioyned them≈øelues. Their captaine was Iulius Briganticus Ciuilis ≈øi≈øters ≈øonne, mortally hating his vnckle, and hated againe: as commonly the enmities of neare≈øt kinsfolkes, if once they fall out, are mo≈øt di≈øpitefull and deadly.
Tutor increa≈øed his power con≈øi≈øting of Treueri with a fre≈øh ≈øupply of Vangiones, Caracates, and Triboci, and that which added mo≈øt ≈øtrength with olde experienced Legionary ≈øouldiers, both footemen and hor≈øe, ≈øome corrupted with hope, and others aw√´d with feare: who at the fir≈øt killed a cohort ≈øent before by Sextilius Felix, and anone when the Roman captaines and armies approched, redeeming their former fault fled ouer to them, and were followed by the Triboci, Vangiones and Caracates. So Tutor being left alone with his Treueri e≈øchewing Magontiacum fled to Bingium, tru≈øting vpon the ≈øtrength of the place, becau≈øe hee had broken downe the bridge of the riuer Naua: but Sextilius with his cohortes following his foote≈øteppes, and finding a forde di≈øcried his power, and ouerthrew it. This di≈øcomfiture vtterly di≈øcouraged the Treueri: and the common people ca≈øting their weapons away returned to their husbandry. And certaine of the nobility that they might ≈øeeme to bee formo≈øt in laying ho≈øtility a≈øide, fled to tho≈øe citties for refuge which had not broken with the Romans. The Legions, which, as before wee declared, went by commaundement from Noue≈øium and Bonna to Triers, voluntarily re≈øumed the oath to Ve≈øpa≈øian. The≈øe things were done in the ab≈øence of Valentinus: who at his returne, in a de≈øperate fury and rage ≈øtirred the coales, and kindled the fire anew. Whereupon the Legions got them away to the Mediomatrici, a ≈øtate in league with the Romans: and Valentinus and Tutor per≈øwaded the Treueri to take vp their weapons againe, and goe to the fielde, hauing fir≈øt killed Herennius and Numi≈øius the Lieutenants, to the intent that being without all hope of pardon, they might be more fa≈øtly vnited together in their wicked con≈øpiracy.

div.head: XXX. Petilius Cerealis ouerthroweth the Treueri, taketh ∆≤alentinus aliue, adioyneth the two Legions from the Mediomatrici, and maketh an oration to the Treueri.
div.p:
THIS was the ≈øtate of the warre, when Petilius Cerealis came to Magontiacum, and by his pre≈øence ray≈øed greate expectation, and hope of our ≈øide. Cerealis him≈øelfe was de≈øirous of the battaile, and hauing a better grace ≈øometime to contemne the enemyes, then alwayes to beware them, with lu≈øtie couragious wordes hee inflamed his ≈øouldier, as
purpo≈øing, ≈øo ≈øoone as he could ouertake the enemies without delay to ioyne i≈ø≈øue in fielde. A ≈øupply of ≈øoldiers ≈øent out of Fraunce he turned home againe, willing them to ≈øignifie ≈øo much to the re≈øt in his name, that the RomaÃÑ Legions ≈øuffized for the defence of the Roman Empire: & that al our good frends & allies ≈øhould returne to their peaceable bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, without further care, a≈ø≈øuring them≈øelues that the warre, now that the Romans per≈øonally vndertooke it, was as good as already di≈øpatched. That increa≈øed the obedience of the French: for hauing receiued their men backe againe, they ≈øupported more ea≈øily al taxes & tributes, and were the more ready to perfourme all pointes of their duety, becau≈øe they ≈øawe their helpe was not needed. But Ciuilis and Cla≈øsicus, whenas they heard of the ouerthrowe of Tutor, the ≈ølaughter of the Treueri, and the good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe euery where of their enemies, all in a fright and ha≈øt ≈øeeke to vnite their di≈øper≈øed powers, ≈øending me≈ø≈øengers in the meane time to Valentinus one after another, warning him to take heede to the maine chance, & not ra≈øhly to venture & hazard the battel. With ≈øo much the more expeditioÃÑ Cerealis di≈øpatched to the Mediomatrici, lying nearer vpon the enemy, certaine to leade the two Legions thence to a≈ø≈øaile them on that ≈øide: & a≈ø≈øembling all the ≈øoldiers at Magontiacum, and the power which he had brought with him ouer the mountaines, him≈øelfe marched forwarde, and at the thirde remooue came to Rigodulum, a place naturally ≈øtrong by rea≈øon of the high ≈øituation, and the riuer Mo≈øella clo≈øing it in: where Valentinus with a great power of Treueri was encamped, and had made it ≈øtronger by arte, ca≈øting trenches and ditches about it, and mighty huge ≈øtones to hinder the pa≈ø≈øage. But the≈øe fortifications terrified the Roman captaine nothing at all, but boldly hee bad the footemen breake thorow, and appointed his battell of hor≈øemen to clime vp the mountaine, de≈øpi≈øing the enemy, whom he knew to be rawe, and vnskilfull in ≈øeruice, and not to haue that aduantage by the difference of place, that him≈øelfe had by the difference of men. At the going vp of the hill ≈øome litle ≈øtay was made, vntill the enemies had ≈øpent their arrowes and dartes: then comming to handy ≈øtroakes, they were driuen downe headlong, & tumbled one ouer another, as it were ≈øtones at the fall of a building: & part of the hor≈øemen fetching about by ea≈øier a≈øcents tooke many of the chiefe nobility of Belgium pri≈øoners, and among≈øt others Valentinus Generall that day
of the fielde. the next day Cerealis entred the towne of Triers. The ≈øouldiers were extremely de≈øirous to raze the citty, alleadging, that here Cla≈øsicus, here Tutor was borne: here were the men through who≈øe wicked con≈øpiracy the Legions were be≈øieged and ≈ølaine. what had poore Cremona de≈øerued ≈øo greatly, as to be rooted out of the body of Italie, becau≈øe it differred the victory onely one night? here in the confines of Germanie ≈øtoode the ≈øeatetowne of rebellion entier, & triumphing with the ≈øpoiles, and ≈ølaughter of our armies and Generals. As for the ≈øpoile he might at his plea≈øure di≈øpo≈øe of to the Princes behoofe, they could be contented with the burning, and ruines of that rebellious colony, to requite thereby in ≈øome part the de≈øtruction of ≈øo many campes. Cerealis for feare of infamy, if he ≈øhould be thought to noo≈øell his ≈øouldiers in licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe and cruelty, repre≈ø≈øed their anger, and they obeyed, being become now they had left off ciuill warre, of more mode≈øt behauiour al≈øo in forreine. Then the mi≈øerable & pitifull ≈øpectacle of the Legions, which came from the Mediomatrici, drew mens minds to the con≈øideration thereof. How many battailes wee haue fought again≈øt the Cimbri and Teutones, what paines our armies haue taken, and with what ≈øucce≈ø≈øe wee haue handled our ≈øelues in the German warres for your ≈øakes, it is notoriou≈øly knowen; neither doe we therefore with ≈øo much expen≈øe of money and men garde the Rhene for the ≈øafety of Italie, but le≈øt ≈øome other Arioui≈øtus ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe and conquere the kingdome of France. Or doe you thinke your ≈øelues better beloued of Ciuilis and the Batauians, and the Germans ouer the Rhene, then your fathers and grandfathers were of their predece≈ø≈øours? the ≈øame cau≈øes ≈øtill are remaining, and ≈øo will be for euer, to mooue the Germans to pa≈ø≈øe into France; to wit, ≈øatisfying of their plea≈øures and lu≈øts, auarice, and de≈øire of changing ≈øeate, that leauing their mires and de≈øer ‚Ä¢ es, they may take po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of this fruitfull cuntrey, and you the inhabitants thereof. yea but liberty and glorious ≈øhewes are pretended. For if the Romans, which the gods defende, ≈øhould be di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, what els can en≈øue but warres of nations again≈øt nations, and the confu≈øion of the whole worlde. div.p:
IN the meane ≈øea≈øon the enemies began to march, & approched on euery ≈øide in ≈øeueral coÃÑpanies: whom Cerealis permitting to ioine, was blamed by many for ≈øuffring theÃÑ to vnite, with whom he might haue fought ≈øingle, & defeated them ea≈øily being diuided.

Ciuilis thought it expedient to ≈øtay for the Germans comming which dwelt ouer the Rhene, the terrour of which nations would treade vnderfoote the Roman powers: as for the Frenchmen it mattered not much what way they went, being nought els but a pray to the conquerours; and yet the ≈øtrength of France, the Belgians, had either openly declared for them, or at lea≈øt ≈øecretly wi≈øhed them well. Contrarily Tutor affirmed, that by delay the Romans would growe and increa≈øe, ≈øo many whole ho≈øtes comming in from euery ≈øide, one Legion being already tran≈øported out of Britannie, others ≈øent for out of Spaine, and many Legions at hande out of Italie, not of raw ≈øouldiers, but olde and well expert in warre: as for the Germans they looked for, what were they els but a kinde of vnprofitable troubles of a campe, out of all awe and obedience to ≈øuperiours, that would not be commanded nor ruled, but doe all as they li≈øted them≈øelues? Now for money and gifts, the onely meanes to corrupt the Germans, the Romans had more abundancee, and no man was ≈øo ha≈øty to fight, but would rather chu≈øe quietne≈ø≈øe then danger with the ≈øame hire. Whereas if they would pre≈øently fight, Cerealis had no other Legions as yet, but onely the remnants of the German army entaÃÑgled with an oath to the Empire of France. And moreouer this their late vnlooked for ≈øucce≈ø≈øe again≈øt Valentinus, and his rude vntrained company, would be a bait vnto them and their General to further ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe, and therefore they would without doubt venture againe, and ≈øo fall into the handes not of an vnskilful youth, better ≈øeene in words and babble, then armes and militare feates, but of Ciuilis and Cla≈øsicus; at the very ≈øight of whom the enemies would tremble, calling to remembrance their former feares, and flightes, and famines, and how oft they had beene taken and pardoned their liues. Neither doe the Treueri and Lingones keepe in with the Romans now vpon loue and goodwill, but for feare: which take ye away and they will re≈øume their weapons againe. Cla≈øsicus approuing rhe opinion of Tutor decided the controuer≈øie, and forthwith they proceede to execution. The middle battell was a≈øsigned to the Vbij and Lingones, on the right ≈øide ≈øtoode the Batauian cohorts, on the lefte

In which confu≈øion Cerealis behauing him≈øelfe without all feare, with his owne handes drew backe them which fled away, & manfully, albeit vnarmed among ≈øo many weapons, with his fortunate ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe, and the as≈øi≈øtance of ≈øome valiant ≈øouldiers comming in, recouered the bridge, and left a cho≈øen company of men to garde it. "Whereupon being full of indignation and wrath, You for≈øake not (quoth he) Hordeonius or Vocula, you can alleadge no fal≈øehood or trea≈øon in me: neyther euer did I commit any act that needed excu≈øe, ≈øaue onely in affirming you had forgotten your oath to France, and remembred your allegeance to the Roman Empire.
